lead_paragraph: To the Editor of the New-York Times: The elections are now over. The country has decided between the policy of the President and Congress. The Fortieth Congress will reflect the same sentiments held by the Thirty-ninth, and being backed by the people upon issues fairly made by the President, the Congress will have more will for action, and will be more pressed to take decided measure than heretofore.

lead_paragraph: To the Editor of the New-York Times. The original plan of the Convention of 1787 contemplated the election of the president by Congress. It was well understood that the choice of one branch of the Government should be vested in the people of the several States; but who were to be these people? There was a tide of emigration flowing to the country, to be constantly increased--people differing in language, principles and intelligence.

lead_paragraph: The horse show that closed last night has undoubtedly been the most successful popular amusement that has ever been offered in this city. The attendance has been at least 80,000, which is probably a considerable understatement. Even so, it is quite unprecedented. When the baseball craze was at its height, there was never anything approaching an average attendance at the games of 13,000 people every day for a week.

lead_paragraph: Modern wiseacres insist that we of the ancient cult are mere things of straw. Well, so be it; straws show which way the wind blows, and so shall I. Too long have I been ignored and forgotten; too long, to use an apt vulgarism, have I had no show. Now, as tutelary divinity of the metropolis, I shall have shows galore, including every Spring the greatest one on earth.

lead_paragraph: LONG BRANCH, N.J., March 18. -- The storm continues to rage along the coast, and much damage is being done. It toppled over upon the strand and is being demolished by the surf.

lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Oct. 20 -- Gen. Harrison started from Fort Wayne on his return trip to Indianapolis this morning. His route to-day was a triangular one -- northwest from Fort Wayne to Plymouth, southwest to Lafayette, and southeast to this city. His first speech was at Columbia City, where he urged protection on the authority of a letter written by Andrew Jackson and accused the Democrats of being subservient to British influences.

The result is that the Garden is stocked with cattle, sheep, swine, poultry, farm produce, fruit, and vegetables.

Brown, has been accused of heretical teaching by conservative members of the congregation, and a council of about a dozen neighboring churches has been summoned to deal with the matter.

lead_paragraph: It was a day of painful success for Charles W. Miller in the fifth day of the six days' cycling at the Garden yesterday. Hour after hour he pedaled stubbornly forward, breaking records with almost every turn of the track. Early in the evening Miller was nearly ninety miles beyond the nearest rider, and was 230 miles ahead of previously existing records.

Miss Crosby, who is known all through the Maine forests as "Fly Rod," entertained a host of sportsmen last night.

lead_paragraph: LONDON, July 29. -- The American dramatic invasion of London closed for the season when the curtain fell on "Sue" at the Garrick Theatre to-night. lead_paragraph: The local delegates who attended the National Assembly in Providence last week still believe that the League of American Wheelmen should have abolished racing. The local delegation wanted no offices, but were willing to sacrifice everything to bring this about. They were beaten, however, by an overwhelming majority, and while they are much disappointed at the way the vote went, it is not their intention to give up the fight against racing.

lead_paragraph: The Horse Show crowd attained the limit of Horse Show possibilities last night, when it crowded the topmost gallery in Madison Square Garden. The people who succeeded in reaching that point were among the least satisfied of the thousands present, for they could see nothing but the horses, and could not by any possibility be seen by any except persons equally unfortunate, which cut out much of the enjoyment of the occasion.

lead_paragraph: Sousa comes again to the Metropolitan Opera House this evening for the first of his Spring series of popular concerts of military music. The soloists for the first concert are Blanche Duffield, soprano, and Bertha Bucklin, violiniste, who have been heard at the Metropolitan before. The chief instrumentalists, as heretofore, will be Mr. Arthur Pryor, whom a Brussels paper last Summer dubbed "the Paganini of the trombone."

lead_paragraph: At 11 o'clock last night, forty-two hours after the start of the fire, the wrecked building of the Equitable Life Assurance Society, at Broadway and Cedar Street, was still ablaze. lead_paragraph: EXCAVATION CAMP, UTICA, Tunis, March 1. -- Remote antiquity and the twentieth century stood in dramatic contrast today when the Franco-American expedition started an entirely new field of archaeological research -- the excavation of Utica. The thick layer of soil which now covers this oldest Punic city of North Africa, founded 500 years before Carthage, now forms part of one of the most modern farms in the world.

headline.main: STARTS EXCAVATION OF ANCIENT UTICA; Count de Prorok Hopes to Find in the Punic City a North African Pompeii. lead_paragraph: AUSTIN-America may be developing a sort of reverse Gulag Archipelago in its midst. lead_paragraph: Lakewood, site of a nationally known summer stock theater here for 79 years, was sold Saturday for $66,000 to the friends of Lakewood, a nonprofit corporation formed this year to keep the theater alive. The group was the only bidder for the theater, which was founded in 190l and which was in 1967 designated by the Legislature as the official theater of the State of Maine. It was part of a theatrical resort that was auctioned off in three major parcels so that Lance Crocker Associates, debtors holding the property, could pay off $350,000.

lead_paragraph: A computerized welfare system has not only cut costs, state officials assert, but has also improved the delivery of services to the poor. Applicants can fill out a single form and be certified for public aid in about two days instead of the two to three weeks previously required. The state should save about $3.9 million a year in administrative costs and an additional $15 million in erroneous payments to ineligible recipients by 1982, said Bernard Stumbras, division administrator for the state's Department of Health and Social Services and the developer of the automated system. By NATHANIEL SHEPPARD Jr, Special to the New York Times MADISON, Wis. - A computerized welfare system has not only cut costs, state officials assert, but has also improved the delivery of services to the poor.

lead_paragraph: The formal identification of a man slain in Wisconsin on March 18 as William H. Callahan, the subject of embezzlement inquiries, was made in Kenosha, Wis., by his daughter, Eleanor Callahan of New Rochelle, N.Y. Miss Callahan, who is 24 years old, was accompanied by James J. Maloney of Rogers & Wells, a lawyer for the Arc Electrical Construction Company. Mr. Callahan was a former executive of the construction concern. Mr. Callahan is also survived by his wife, the former Eleanor Rao, and two sons, William Jr., 26, and Charles, 20. The Arc company had filed a State Supreme Court civil suit against Mr. Callahan for alleged embezzlement and had brought the case to the Manhattan District Attorney.

lead_paragraph: THE 250th birthday of Philip Mazzei, the Italian-American patriot, will be celebrated next Saturday at Fairleigh Dickinson University here. The program, called ''Philip Mazzei's Role: Age of the Enlightment'' and financed by the state's Committee for the Humanities, is open to the public. It will offer lectures, discussion, exhibitions and Italian songs and dances. ''Move over, Benjamin Franklin -and Lafayette and Kosciusko, too,'' said Sister Margherita Marchione of Morristown, professor of Italian language and literature at Fairleigh Dickinson and director of the program. ''Make room in the history books for a brilliant contemporary who, like you, was tirelessly devoted to the cause of American independence.''

lead_paragraph: They are a diverse lot: One is a former marine, another taught autistic children, a third was a computer expert for the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. But they were drawn together by a call to the Protestant ministry, and today they will receive Master of Divinity degrees from Drew Theological School in Madison, N.J. In general, the class of 1981 reflects a more elastic concept of the ministry than that held by the traditional Protestant clergy, and its members have chosen a wider variety of means for achieving it. For some, it will be the parish; for others, a specialized service or part-time parish duties. ''There is a different view of the ministry now,'' said Robert Gee, who will become the assistant pastor at the Hicksville, L.I., Methodist Church. ''It used to be 'once in the ministry always in the ministry,' but now it's 'if not this, something else.' ''

lead_paragraph: MADISON ALTHOUGH it is not on the shore, Friends & Company - located in a modern-looking shingled building on the Post Road - is reported to be one of this resort town's most popular restaurants. Certainly our observation during several meals there would bear this out. The small, rustic dining room is packed and there is usually a waiting line. A glance at the moderate prices on the menu explains part of the popularity. The menu is limited to just a few dishes capably prepared, which may also be a clue to the restaurant's success. But there is more than that. There are several congenial touches that make Friends & Company an informal friendly place to go for lunch or a light family-style dinner.

lead_paragraph: MADISON THE recent marriage of Prince Charles may have given England's sagging spirits a temporary lift, but one doubts if John Osborne was comforted by the royal wedding. Still, it is probable that the honest, biting and altogether professional revival of ''The Entertainer,'' now being performed as part of the New Jersey Shakespeare Festival at Drew University, might win the approval of Mr. Osborne, a dramatist who has toppled dozens of monarchical, political and domestic icons on John Bull's once untouchable isle. Mr. Osborne's play, exported from London to New York in 1958, was more than a vehicle that helped Laurence Olivier descend from a classical pinnacle and deliver the tawdry puns of Archie Rice, the script's rueful, leering and grinning ne'er-do-well. ''The Entertainer'' was, and remains, a gargoyle of an evening. Its grotesque protagonist - a faded, bloody and bowed vaudevillian - taunts his music-hall audiences with decrepit jests and carves a virtual tomb in which his relatives thrash about helplessly while they enact their tale of a moribund family, one that is set against an Empire in ruins.

lead_paragraph: IN ALL its 31 years, the Madison-based Colonial Symphony has never ventured beyond Morris County. However, things are looking up - or, to be geographically precise, down - because the 46-member ensemble is going to Washington in March for an appearance at the Kennedy Center. The occasion is the new ''American Portraits'' concert series, a celebration of music by contemporary American composers that is being coordinated by the Colonial's conductor, Paul Zukofsky. The series will encompass 15 concerts over the next three years. It will feature a variety of musical groups, and each concert will be devoted to a single composer.

lead_paragraph: MADISON ''OLOVE is the crooked thing,'' wrote William Butler Yeats. Moreover, the winding paths that divide or unite a father and son are beautifully trod in Hugh Leonard's ''Da,'' now being triumphantly presented by the New Jersey Shakespeare Festival at Drew University. Wearing a mourning band on his sleeve and exposing a heart at which all birds can gnaw, Charlie (Kenneth Gray) is a handsome, middle-aged man who has recently buried his foster father. He rifles through an arsenal of souvenirs, dons his spectacles and shivers with past reveries as his family and friends return to haunt his kitchen, one that is artfully designed by Peter Harrison and evocatively lighted by Richard Dorfman.

lead_paragraph: MADISON GEORGE GROSZ was born in Berlin in 1893 and he died there (in the western part) 66 years later. Having left Germany during the 30's as a ''degenerate artist,'' he had returned a few years before his death as a highly respected figure, fit to be elected Extraordinary Member of the Berlin Academy of Art. The intervening period was spent as a citizen of the United States, where he taught for many years at the Art Students League and where, in 1954, he enjoyed a retrospective at the Whitney Museum. There have been many posthumous shows of Grosz's work, of which that now (through Nov. 14) at the Korn Gallery of Drew University is the most recent. It's a meager affair, consisting mainly of the lithographed drawings that the artist customarily issued in portfolios and a couple of original works in pencil and they are pinned to the walls unframed and skimpily documented.

lead_paragraph: MADISON A SERIES of rapes and attempted rapes around this small, coastal town have prompted officials at the Dr. Robert H. Brown Middle School to initiate a program designed to prepare young people to cope with crisis situations. Entitled ''Decreasing Vulnerability,'' the program consists of lectures and seminars in which guidance counselors and other faculty members pose crisis-oriented problems to the school's 816 sixth-, seventh- and eighth-grade students. ''We're not only addressing rape,'' said Marcia Myhre, a guidance counselor at the school, ''although so many rapes have occurred that we are concerned.'' Students have been asked, for example, what they should do if they arrive home from school alone and find a normally locked door open, or what they should do if the people for whom they were baby-sitting arrive home intoxicated and insist on driving them home.

lead_paragraph: Seventy-four-year-old Phineas Meigs was reportedly the last Connecticut soldier to die in one of the last battles of the Revolutionary War, a little-known skirmish that took place in Madison 200 years ago this month. The residents will commemorate the event with a reenactment beginning at 1:15 P.M. next Sunday, following an encampment of uniformed troops and their families on the green Saturday. A memorial service will be held at 10 A.M. Saturday at Meigs's grave. His 1690 home will be the starting point for Sunday's troop movements, and his tattered hat, the only remaining relic of his travail, will be on display in the library.

lead_paragraph: MADISON IN TURNING Shakespeare's 15-hour gargantuan tetralogy (''Henry VI,'' Parts I, II and III, and ''Richard III'') into a nine-hour trilogy (''Henry VI,'' ''Edward IV'' and ''Richard III'') that is being performed over three separate evenings under the overall title of ''War of the Roses,'' Paul Barry, the New Jersey Shakespeare Festival's director and adapter, is setting a local record for sheer enormity and establishing a new endurance test for festival audiences. Even though some 30 characters have been eliminated by Mr. Barry's editing, 200 roles, played by 80 actors, remain. That is the largest cast and budget ($365,000) in the festival's 11-year history. ''Henry VI'' in its entirety and ''Richard III'' have been performed only twice together in this century, once in the United States (12 years ago) and once in England (19 years ago).

lead_paragraph: Every summer since 1938, Dr. Harry J. Johnson, a Manhattan internist, and his wife, Teresa, have vacationed in Madison, Conn., a town of 15,000 on Long Island Sound. ''We enjoyed living here,'' Dr. Johnson said, ''and five years ago, when I retired, we began to think of how we could help the town, something of lasting benefit.'' The solution, announced this week, has stunned and pleased Madison. Dr. Johnson, who is 80 years old, and his wife have donated $1 million to pay for two annual college scholarships for graduates of the local high school. Up to $8,000 will be made available to each recipient, a boy and a girl, for each of four years.

lead_paragraph: ''IT'S a blessing and it's a curse,'' Juliette Koka said of her much-acclaimed identification with Edith Piaf. Her solo show about the late tragic chanteuse, often called ''The Little Sparrow,'' originated as a showcase in Fort Lee, was expanded into a Broadway play in 1977 and has since reverted to a one-woman piece, which Miss Koka has performed in cabarets, concert halls and theaters. For the Finnish-born singing actress who has lived in New Jersey for 30 years (she and her husband, Bob Wollman, a businessman, moved to Englewood Cliffs 11 years ago after 19 years in Fort Lee), playing Piaf has become something of an annuity. Miss Koka would not mind taking her Piaf act on the road, continuing on the college circuit (which she has played in part) and perpetuating the Piaf legend for new generations and old aficionados, and shaking up the stereotype of Piaf as a drug- and drink-ridden woman of the streets who ''went up on her lines,'' as is commonly believed.

lead_paragraph: On a bluff overlooking the Ohio River near the small farming community of Madison in southern Indiana, the Marble Hill nuclear power project is less than half completed and all but overwhelmed by increasing costs and growing uncertainty over how to finance them. In many ways, therefore, it is like a number of other nuclear power projects around the country; most prominently those of the Washington Public Power Supply System and the Long Island Lighting Company. In one way, however, it is different: Marble Hill may be the last American reactor of its era. Since it was ordered, in 1974, all of the 32 other reactors ordered in that year have been canceled, along with all of the 15 reactors ordered in subsequent years, because of rising construction costs, high interest rates and slack demand for electricity.

lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether the Oneida Indians had the right to sue two upstate New York counties for ''wrongful occupation'' of their ancestral lands. The case, which turns on the interpretation of a 1793 Federal law, has broad implications for Indian land claims throughout the Northeast. The Court accepted two appeals from a lower Federal court ruling in favor of the Oneida Indian Nation. The group had filed a test case in 1970 involving 872 acres in Madison and Oneida Counties, near Utica. The Federal District Court ruled that the Indians' claim to the land was valid and awarded them $16,700 in damages. The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit upheld the ruling.

lead_paragraph: The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in Manhattan was designed to be a temple of the law. Its facade includes statues of Moses, Confucius and Justinian. Murphy Jr., the area surrounding the building, particularly Madison Square Park, could be the subject of a tableau depicting the flouting of the law. As Justice Murphy describes it, the painting would depict drug dealers and their customers doing business, with apparent impunity, on the steps of the courthouse itself.

lead_paragraph: Speaking in a state and a city noted for political independence, Gary Hart today called on Democrats to break with ''the failed leadership and failed policies'' of the party's past. ''As much as we want to remove Ronald Reagan, that will not be as easy as it seems,'' said the Colorado Senator, who is seeking the Democratic Presidential nomination. He addressed one of the biggest crowds of his campaign, at least 2,000 people, on the steps of the state Capitol here atop a hill in the center of the city on a sunny, warm day. On Tuesday, while he was being resoundingly defeated in New York State by Walter Mondale, Mr. Hart nosed out Mr. Mondale in this state's nonbinding primary, in which, unlike the closed New York primary, independents and Democrats can cross over and vote in the Democratic contest. On Saturday, Wisconsin will begin the process of choosing convention delegates in caucuses.

lead_paragraph: Out-of-towners who think New York is unfriendly, and most of them do, ought to come to my Carnegie Hill neighborhood and talk to a few of the merchants. Along with the traditional mom-and-pop corner store and boutiques similar to those that have transformed the landscape of areas like Columbus Avenue, the two blocks on Madison Avenue between 88th and 90th streets are chock-full of merchants who find the area as friendly as any small town. In the two and a half years that I have lived around the corner five shops selling food have opened, bringing the total to six. Now within two minutes of my apartment I can buy chocolate truffles made daily, sip one of the best cups of coffee in the city while I munch a delectable pastry, choose from a selection of 100 cheeses or decide to make a last-minute dinner from a handsome array of carry-out salads. My gastronomic impulses can be satisfied from seven in the morning until nine at night during the week and midnight on Saturdays.

lead_paragraph: The Bank of America, long considered an out-of-town cousin when it comes to New York financial dealings, formally opened its new regional headquarters on Madison Avenue yesterday. To do so, it had gutted the Biltmore Hotel and its famous Palm Court. But the San Francisco-based bank retained the legendary Biltmore lobby clock as the centerpiece of the renovated 28-story structure, perhaps hoping to receive the kind of attention that the clock had as the designated New York meeting place for people the world over.

lead_paragraph: MORRISTOWN A FILM on the Revolutionary War winter of 1779-80, as seen through the eyes of an 18th-century Presbyterian clergyman here, is scheduled to be shown in the fall on public-television stations across the country. The film, ''Hard Winter,'' was made on location in this community, not far from the town of Madison, which was known as Bottle Hill 200 years ago. That was when the Rev. Ebenezer Bradford, 27-year-old parson of the local Presbyterian meetinghouse, was making his deep-felt feelings known from the pulpit. The young clergyman was seen as a level-headed man, someone to be listened to, but also as somewhat of a radical because of his beliefs.

lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''Choking Fifth Avenue'' recognizes the problems caused by the proliferation of express buses on Fifth and Madison Avenues (editorial Aug. 27), but fails to note that the city has been taking aggressive action to address these concerns. Our planning strategies recognize it is more efficient to carry people in buses than in private cars. As the demand for transport from the boroughs has grown, so have the need and demand for buses into Manhattan. Although their numbers have created problems, the service they offer fosters economic growth and commercial vitality.

lead_paragraph: Standing outside Isabel Canovas, a two-month-old couture accessories shop on Madison Avenue, its manager, Bimia Picot, scrunched her nose in discreet distaste when questioned about an even more recent arrival, The Limited. On Monday, one of the country's fastest-growing chains of sportswear specialty retailers will open a store at the 62d Street corner of New York's most prestigious shopping strip. The Limited will occupy a landmark 1928 McKim, Mead & White building that originally housed Louis Sherry's ice cream parlor. It shares the 19,500-square-foot space with its subsidiaries, Limited Express, specializing in clothes for young women, and Victoria's Secret, a lingerie shop. All three Limited divisions sell cutting-edge fashion at prices far below the Madison Avenue norm.

''We're trying to understand what happened and what it meant,'' said the president, Kenneth Keller. ''But we're not looking for scapegoats, we're not looking for a pound of flesh.'' lead_paragraph: Joseph Paul Franklin, a convicted murderer who has been a suspect in a series of racially motivated shootings from Pennsylvania to Utah, will go on trial here Monday for the 1977 slaying of an interracial couple in a shopping mall parking lot. Mr. Franklin, who recently asked the court to forbid reporters to call him a racist, confessed the parking lot slayings in a 1984 police interview, according to the criminal charges. Last month, Judge William D. Byrne of Dane County Court rejected Mr. Franklin's request that his 1984 statements be suppressed. Mr. Franklin, 35 years old, who has pleaded not guilty to the murder charges, will be allowed to defend himself, though a lawyer has been appointed in case he requires aid.

lead_paragraph: Joseph Paul Franklin, who is already serving a prison term for killing two blacks in Utah, was convicted today in the deaths of an interrracial couple that a prosecutor said were close to ''killing for sport.'' Mr. Franklin was charged with shooting Alphonse Manning Jr. and Toni Schwenn in a parking lot here on Aug. 7, 1977. Mr. Manning was black and Miss Schwenn was white. Both were 23 years old. The jury in Dane County Circuit Court deliberated about two hours before finding Mr. Franklin guilty of two counts of first-degree murder, which carries a mandatory sentence of life in prison. Judge William D. Byrne immediately sentenced Mr. Franklin to two consecutive life terms.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art argues that the masterpiece should be housed in its American Wing, as a long-term loan. The statue was at the Met earlier this winter, in the same show that opened yesterday at the Boston Museum of Fine Arts.

lead_paragraph: Since July 9, 1776, when New York patriots, on first hearing the Declaration of Independence, pulled down the statue of George III, public sculpture has had the power to move Americans. Now, another statue raises important public issues. It is the bronze Admiral (''Damn the torpedoes - full speed ahead!'') Farragut by Augustus St. Gaudens, a great American 19th century sculptor. This splendid work, commissioned for New York's Madison Square Park, was unveiled in 1881. The architect Stanford White designed for it a superb stone pedestal-bench, and the two parts together represent a landmark in this nation's sculpture. Farragut, commander of the Union fleet, defeated the Confederate forces in the battle of New Orleans, and the work, like so much sculpture of that period, commemorates the heroism of the Civil War.

lead_paragraph: Innovative programs scattered around the country are offering the first rays of hope in decades for millions of tormented victims of schizophrenia, which has become the nation's worst mental health problem. ''We've learned that if we have the will to provide decent care for schizophrenics, their condition could be sharply improved,'' said John Talbott, a former president of the American Psychiatric Association. But other experts say the growing ability to cope with schizophrenia is not being matched by a broad, coordinated effort to apply it. That failure, they say, is enormously costly to the nation both in the money spent for excessive hospitalization and in the shattered, unrepaired lives that result. Schizophrenia's victims can be completely disabled by unsettling delusions or an inability to think clearly; they may find themselves shouting back wildly at imaginary voices or sinking, emotionless, into deep apathy.

lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Joan K. Davidson's March 15 Op-Ed article on the prospective move of Augustus St.-Gaudens's statue of Adm. David Farragut from New York City's Madison Square Park to the courtyard of the American Wing in the Metropolitan Museum of Art touched on a very important issue. The well-being of public art in American cities has been ignored and neglected for too long. The Parks Department and the Central Park Conservancy have struggled to maintain the city's public statuary with limited budgets and private funds. The pollution and vandalism of urban environments are hostile to works of art in stone and bronze. Nineteenth-century stone sculptures displayed outdoors are in such bad condition that many have suffered irreparable damage. Though there are several ways to clean and preserve bronze in outdoor settings, no single one is considered both safe and suitable. The cardinal rule in conservation is reversibility (that is, that any treatment undertaken on a work of art can be undone, leaving no effect). Relocating any statue to an interior space, whether the Metropolitan Museum, City Hall or a sculpture museum - the Bargello in Florence, say - is unequivocally reversible.

lead_paragraph: To Irving Powless Jr., the chief of the Onondaga Indian Nation, the people of New York are his guests - guests in an Iroquois longhouse that ''covers what is now called New York State.'' To Allan van Gestel, a lawyer for Madison and Oneida Counties in north central New York, east of Syracuse, New Yorkers living on land once owned by Indians ''are nothing less than hostages in a power struggle between three governments - Federal, state and Indian.'' Mr. Powless and Mr. van Gestel were among the speakers at a symposium at Colgate University on Indian land claims that was held last weekend, one year after the United States Supreme Court ruled that the Oneida Nation could collect rent from Madison and Oneida Counties on land illegally purchased from the Indians 190 years earlier. The disputed 900-acre parcel, which straddles the border between the counties, was an important test for the Oneidas and Cayugas, two Iroquois nations that claim broad swaths of land in New York, from Pennsylvania to Canada.

Now, with the opening yesterday of Polo/Ralph Lauren, a 20,000-square-foot store at 867 Madison Avenue, at the corner of 72d Street, Mr. Lauren - who is often quoted as having based his merchandising concepts on ''creating dreams'' - has built his ultimate ancestral dream home. At issue was whether to conserve the 19th-century bronze by isolating it from an increasingly hostile environment or to preserve it in the public setting for which it was intended.

lead_paragraph: MADISON AVENUE, the symbolic home of the advertising world, is not exactly what it used to be - an address reserved for well-known big-city agencies: * A. James Matson, the grocery group president of Pet Inc. in St. Louis, spent months last year looking for the right agency to advertise the company's Accent food enhancer. ''We looked at a lot of New York agencies,'' he said, ''but we found that the freshest creative work was being done in the outlying areas.'' The company chose the Martin Agency, in Richmond, Va. * L.S. Heath & Sons took its $6 million Heath candy-bars-and-confections business from a New York agency and gave it to a Minneapolis agency, Fallon & McElligott, earlier this year. Bloomingdale's awarded the agency a special projects campaign. * The International Advertising Film Festival, held in Cannes and Venice, has bestowed the Gold Lion award - its highest accolade for creativity in a television commercial - on a Seattle agency, Livingston & Company, for the past two years. At national award shows, upstarts from towns like Raleigh, N.C., Minneapolis and Portland, Ore., are thrashing the advertising establishment. ''Regionals have won most of the awards because their work is better than what is coming out of New York,'' said Angela Dominguez, director of New York's prestigious One Show awards.

lead_paragraph: On Madison Avenue above 60th Street, boutique after boutique has been fitted into former brownstone after brownstone, and what a decade ago was still a neighborhood street for the Upper East Side has gradually become an international shopping district reminiscent of the great shopping streets in Europe. In the last two years the trend has intensified, and the international section of Madison Avenue, centered in the 60's, has expanded dramatically. The area between 59th and 72d Streets is now consolidated into a type of linear department store, anchored by the new Maxim's restaurant at 61st Street on one end, Polo Ralph Lauren Madison Avenue at 72d on the other and the recently remodeled Westbury Hotel in between. Area Poised to Expand Along with its high-profile identity, the dozen-block stretch has developed the efficient ''loop'' organization of a shopping mall, where shoppers stroll up one side to an anchor store and then return down the other side. At night the street is a long line of small, brightly lighted stages.

The proposal has set off a storm in city government. City Planning Department officials rejected an early design for the building and, according to a lawyer for the developer, they are opposing the current application, too.

lead_paragraph: In the early morning hours of Oct. 14, fire destroyed the only high school in this small blue-collar town in central Maine. It was a heavy blow to townspeople, but the loss has paled in comparison with what was to come. There have been five more fires and one near-fire, all believed by investigators to be arson, in the two months since the high school was destroyed, leaving residents frightened and bewildered. Fires have also struck the junior high school, a dairy warehouse and three houses, one of which was occupied. The cumulative damage was estimated over $2 million. Nobody was injured.

lead_paragraph: For 32 years, Representative Robert W. Kastenmeier has been one of the semi-anonymous people who make Congress work even when it looks as if it's falling apart, toiling on obscure committees on important projects with little political reward, regularly re-elected by districts that they seem to match perfectly in ideology, ethnic background and temperament. An old-fashioned liberal Democrat, a civil-rights and civil-liberties advocate all his life, he has represented the Madison, Wis., area, not as a crusader but as a legislative craftsman. Quiet-spoken and polite, dogged, a bit austere, he was senior to all but 10 members of the House, and he was the second-ranking member of the powerful House Judiciary Committee.

lead_paragraph: Madison Avenue, at least the glitzy stretch of it from the 60's to the mid-70's, is rarely less than fashionable, but last Sunday afternoon it seemed even more fashionable than usual. Ten blocks were closed to traffic, and became, for a few hours anyway, a chic promenade filled with couples and families, many of them dressed to be seen in their classic Sunday-best topcoats or more up-to-the-moment long jacket and tights combinations. F.A.O. Schwarz pitched a tent in the middle of the street, and parked in front of Ralph Lauren was a lovingly restored 1954 Morgan sportster that the store was selling for $50,000. All of this was in support of a worthy cause, for most of the merchants along this stretch of Madison donated 20 percent of all sales to five New York charities for needy children.

lead_paragraph: Monday night's show by the Grateful Dead, the second of nine at Madison Square Garden, sputtered a bit in the beginning, caught on during the last song of the first set, then took off after intermission. The band, usually at its best during long, improvised sections and segues between songs, stuck to fairly short pieces instead. With unusually precise and swinging drumming, it turned the pieces into taut, well-edited pop tunes. The second set began with "Iko Iko," the New Orleans Mardi Gras song that, with its specific rhythms, was an inspired choice, locking Mickey Hart and Bill Kreutzmann, the Dead's two drummers, into a groove. The band cruised through an energetic version of "Uncle John's Band" and the Rolling Stones' "Last Time," stopped momentarily for a chilly version of "Dark Star" that segued into "One More Saturday Night," and capped the set with a beautifully static "Walk Me Out Into the Morning Dew." The set also included the band's traditional two-drum duet, which metamorphosed into a slow arrhythmic group improvisation.

headline.main: Review/Pop; The Grateful Dead's Continuing Metamorphosis

lead_paragraph: New Jersey, already home to a number of major drug companies, is getting one more. The American Home Products Corporation, one of the nation's largest manufacturers of pharmaceuticals and medical equipment, has decided to move its headquarters from Manhattan to Madison, N.J., the company said. About 1,000 employees now in New York were told on Thursday that they would be asked to transfer by the end of 1993, a company spokesman, John Skule, said. The move will leave only the Bristol-Myers Squibb Corporation and Pfizer Inc. as the major drug manufacturers with headquarters in New York City.

lead_paragraph: Rush's concert at Madison Square Garden on Friday night was so overwhelming that it was easy to forget there were actually three men onstage. Before Geddy Lee, Alex Lifeson and Neil Peart even took the stage, a wide-screen projection showed a vaguely Cubist animated cartoon of the three musicians vaulting through the air with their instruments. Throughout the set, the backdrop intermittently displayed diverse and surreal images of drum kits suspended over water, geometric computer graphics, children gazing at space ships and flying bird's-eye views of landscapes. The music itself was not so much a collection of songs as a nonstop technological force. Mr. Peart, the drummer, seldom played anything as simple as a back beat, instead laying down complex, assaultive patterns with frequent time changes. Mr. Lifeson's speedy, baroque guitar solos added the next textural layer, with their counterpoint in Mr. Lee's florid, melodic bass lines. But during numbers like "Roll the Bones," the title track from Rush's latest album on Atlantic, most of the music seemed to come from prerecorded backing tapes, anyway. Combine this with a film of a skeleton in Wayfarer sunglasses doing an electronic rap, and the musicians themselves were practically invisible.

headline.main: Review/Rock; More Technological Than Human

lead_paragraph: Guns 'n' Roses has staked its reputation on its volatility. W. Axl Rose, its lead singer, is famous for his temper, his onstage tirades and his conviction that self-indulgence plus self-importance equals integrity. The band's songs, which veer from raging hard-rock to wistful ballads, are a secondary draw. Yet when Guns 'n' Roses came to Madison Square Garden on Monday night for the first of three sold-out shows -- the final show is Friday night -- the most surprising part of its set was how routine it seemed. The band has a new lineup for this part of its tour. Izzy Stradlin, the rhythm guitarist who co-wrote many of the songs on "Use Your Illusion" I and II (Geffen), the band's current best-selling albums, has quit, replaced for the tour by Gilbey Clarke. The band has also added two backup singers and three horn players, all women dressed in black lingerie. It's a horn section valued primarily for its G-strings. The women pouted and posed like Motley Crue's backup singers; also like Motley Crue, Guns 'n' Roses had an electronic display to flash its name between the set and encores, like an "Applause" sign.

lead_paragraph: To the Editor: "Stuck at the Airport? Then Look at the Art" (Dec. 15), was especially interesting to me for two reasons. The first is that I think it does take a listing to get people to look at the art around them, and thus by remarking it, to make sure that it is not destroyed or removed or damaged. Because a fine glass mural over the doorways at the Madison airport was casually destroyed when the airport was being enlarged, I undertook to catalogue all Madison's outdoor sculpture in a booklet "A Common Joy: Outdoor Art in Madison" (1991). People tell me they look at things they never really noticed before.

lead_paragraph: FOR decades, the American Forestry Association and the National Association of Homebuilders have been perceived as mortal enemies, with the foresters urging tree conservation and the home builders clear-cutting the land for easier and cheaper construction. But two years ago, in response to environmental concerns, a program was developed in a joint effort by the two adversaries. It is called Global Releaf, and it seeks to teach developers how to achieve more tree preservation, thereby reducing energy costs, absorbing carbon dioxide, slowing erosion, and making properties more salable. Participation is voluntary, and information is distributed through the National Homebuilders Association in Washington.

The officials say the fence is part of a security plan, not an effort to sweep away one of New York's most visible problems. But the question of whether the city would take steps to clear the area of homeless people before the convention has created a delicate situation for the Dinkins administration.

lead_paragraph: MEASURED in square footage alone, the public will lose some room when Sony USA reshapes the base of the former A.T. & T. headquarters on Madison Avenue, into which it is moving this year. But the New York City Planning Commission has approved the transformation, in the belief that the result will be an amenity that is far more engaging and welcoming than the existing arcade and covered pedestrian space. The case illustrates the broader problem faced by owners, planners and the public when privately built amenities -- no matter how well intended -- do not function as planned or do not materialize at all. There is the dance rehearsal studio next to the City Center of Music and Drama that never got built. There is the isolated little East River esplanade to which some neighbors feel uncomfortable going. There is the mid-Manhattan hotel that has taken away the chairs and tables in its atrium.

The 74-year-old writer of children's books was alarmed because in the two years she has tried to persuade dog owners to keep their pets from chasing squirrels, tensions have escalated from scowls and angry words to a point two weeks ago when one member of the squirrel faction told the police that he had been punched by one of the dog owners.

lead_paragraph: LIKE a chrysalis 240 feet high, a bland post-war steel-and-glass office tower at Madison Avenue and 61st Street is being transformed behind tarpaulins into something out of pre-war Paris, with broad limestone pilasters framing delicate black ironwork. When it emerges in September, the first nine floors will house Barneys New York, proclaiming itself the largest specialty store to open in Manhattan since 1929. By virtue of its size -- 240,000 square feet of selling space -- and the thousands of customers it will draw, the impact of Barneys will probably be felt for many blocks around. Indeed, it is already having an effect.

lead_paragraph: REMEMBER the tune "Two Different Worlds"? The latest results from an annual survey of agency-client relationships suggest that it ought to be revived as a theme song for marketers and their Madison Avenue shops. A preview of the 1993 Salz Survey of Advertiser-Agency Relations indicates that the two sides, rarely of one mind about anything, continue to perceive important elements of the work they do together in startlingly disparate ways. The misunderstandings, as revealed in the eighth annual survey, would be comical if not for the fact that they seem to be making themselves felt in the outcome of the campaigns the agencies produce.

lead_paragraph: A day meant for celebration took on a far darker tone this afternoon when at least three people were critically injured and five others were seriously hurt in a crush of fans rejoicing over Wisconsin's 13-10 defeat of Michigan. In all, more than 70 people were taken to three local hospitals as a result of the incident, which came moments after Wisconsin's victory before a sellout crowd of 77,745 at Camp Randall Stadium. As of late last night, 16 people were still hospitalized. The great majority of those injured were reported to be women.

lead_paragraph: This is a a salubrious summer for Wisconsin and its outsize but difficult son, Frank Lloyd Wright. After ignoring his genius for seven decades, the state government is now the sponsor of a $20 million program to restore Taliesin, the architect's eloquent but neglected home in Spring Green, an hour's drive from Madison. In Madison itself, state, city and county governments have joined in a business-promoted plan to build the Monona Terrace Convention and Community Center. Wright drew the original plans without fee in 1938, and revised them before his death in 1959. No less than eight city referendums sprang from arguments over this project, which has been successively approved, disapproved, reborn, reburied and now, it seems, resurrected.

lead_paragraph: AT sundown today, as Hanukkah begins, Roxanne Coady will begin her usual celebration. On each of the holiday's eight days, she will light another candle on the menorah in the window of her store, R. J. Julia Booksellers in Madison, and say a traditional prayer. "We just do that. People outside can see it," said Mrs. Coady. Next Sunday afternoon she will invite people inside for a party, and on other afternoons she will invite them to smaller events featuring Hanukkah stories and traditions. The events, geared to families, are open to all. The party was launched in 1990, the year Mrs. Coady opened her store. Organizers of Madison's annual Christmas Festival and Parade -- sponsored by the Chamber of Commerce -- asked if she would have a story hour for children as part of the festival. Mrs. Coady said she would, but she noted that the 1990 festival occurred during Hanukkah. "I'd also like to do Hanukkah stories and candle lighting," she said.

He spreads a blanket or newspaper on the chilly sidewalk of Madison Avenue and curls up in the golden glow of a store where women buy silks and baubles and other pretty things. Mr. Barbera, one of the hundred or so homeless who spend the night in the alcoves of the ritzy shops on Madison Avenue, can go long hours without speaking to anyone but himself.

lead_paragraph: Sergei Bubka of Ukraine has pole-vaulted five inches higher than anyone else in history. Jackie Joyner-Kersee has won Olympic and world championships in the women's long jump and heptathlon. Hassiba Boulmerka of Algeria has won Olympic and world gold medals in the women's 1,500-meter run. Dennis Mitchell is the world's No. 1-ranked sprinter. Greg Foster had won the Millrose Games' men's hurdles in 10 of the past 15 years. These great track and field athletes have something unpleasant in common. All were beaten badly last night in the 88th annual Chemical Bank Millrose Games, America's blue-ribbon indoor meet. Throw in among the losers Marcus O'Sullivan of Ireland, who had won the glamorous Wanamaker Mile five times in the past nine years, but at least he lost this time by no more than three or four inches.

lead_paragraph: The Mayor's Office of Midtown Enforcement is cracking down on brothels in the Madison Square area. Two weeks ago, Midtown Enforcement, in conjunction with the 13th Precinct and the Manhattan South vice squad, used a nuisance abatement statute to padlock a brothel at 35 East 28th Street, the third such closing in the area in the last few months. In January, a brothel that had masqueraded as a nail salon, at 350 Park Avenue South, was shut down. Later that month, another brothel, at 154 East 28th Street, was padlocked. Authorities say two other recent attempts to open on East 28th and East 29th Streets were thwarted.

lead_paragraph: The Florham Park-Madison campus of Fairleigh Dickinson University is a hidden jewel, with lush gardens and grounds laid out in the 1890's by the Central Park designer Frederick Law Olmsted and his son for the estate being built by Florence Vanderbilt and her husband, Hamilton Twombly. They called their home Florham, a combination of the first syllables of their first names. On 23d Street, a bus kiosk bearing a handbill for actors and models catches the eye of Mr. Fling, the soft-spoken head of Save New York, a loosely knit group of 50 community advocates. "This is filth," he says. Off comes the offending 8-by-11 paper. Kathy Danchise, a Save New York member, laughs: "He's always like this. If you walk with Bill, you're going to have to slow down."

If you guessed it was the moment she decided to stay with her dull yet well-meaning farmer husband instead of fleeing with the dashing, romantic National Geographic photographer Robert Kincaid, you were wrong. Francesca's Regret is an apple dumpling topped with frozen yogurt, caramel sauce and nuts, served here at the fountain of the Montross Pharmacy. Although the pharmacy's co-owner Jim Nelson admitted that you'd have to read between the lines of the "The Bridges of Madison County" "to find that Francesca ever shopped at Montross," his wife, Pat, decided that "after Robert left, this was how Francesca drowned her sorrows."

lead_paragraph: Last month, when the State Education Commissioner, Leo F. Klagholz, announced the latest plan to equalize spending between rich and poor school districts, superintendents around the state held their breath. Yet another attempt to end 25 years of court battles, the new plan was bound to affect some districts for the worse. Under the plan, New Jersey would define the "thorough and efficient" education mandated by the State Constitution in terms of what is taught, not what is spent. Dr. Klagholz wants to set curriculum standards and determine how much they would cost each of more than 600 districts, rather than letting local voters decide on a budget. The state would pay as little as nothing or up to 85 percent of a district's costs to meet the standards, depending on the district's wealth. The rest of the budget would come from local property taxes.

lead_paragraph: Madison Avenue ranks among the world's premier shopping streets. Fashionable and famous emporiums like Polo, Armani and Barneys draw the rich and the recognized, as do the avenue's art galleries and restaurants. Rents for retail space are in league with those for stores on Fifth Avenue, 57th Street and the Ginza in Tokyo. But two years ago the shooting of two customers in a robbery at the exclusive Vera Wang bridal salon, at 77th Street, shocked merchants, moving them to form a business improvement district, the first large one approved by the Council after it lifted a moratorium on new districts so it could study abuses at existing ones and recommend changes. "It is sorely needed to maintain the area's position," said the head of the Madison Avenue Merchants Association, Alexander Kabbaz, who is expected to head the new district when it starts operating in September.

At the Playwrights Theater of New Jersey, it's always process. The state's only theater devoted to the many phases of developing a play -- "developing the dramatic imagination" is the phrase on the theater's stationery -- has been around for 10 years. So it's a fitting time for the artistic director, John Pietrowski, and the founding director, Buzz McLaughlin, to reflect on the growth of a place where the playwright's the thing.

lead_paragraph: MADISON for money, Guilford for class and Clinton for clams." The words came from a happily settled, longtime resident of Clinton, and so could be spoken with impunity, not to say pride. As with most generalizations, there is a germ of truth to this characterization of three historic towns in what is known as the shoreline region of Connecticut, which runs east and slightly north of New Haven along Long Island Sound up toward the Connecticut River Valley towns of Essex and Old Lyme. Driving through the region along the Boston Post Road you'll get a quick impression of the ways in which these shoreline towns are alike and yet different. The first one you pass through on the way east from New Haven is Branford, a warm-up to the other three with its crafts village and its island-dotted coastline. In Guilford you'll see antiques shops, professional offices and a few low-key shopping strips, but the general air is of serene traditionalism, as befits a town with one of the oldest and largest greens in New England and one of the richest collections of still-inhabited pre-Revolutionary houses.

lead_paragraph: WHEN Phillip N. Costello Jr. enrolled in Yale University in 1948, he planned to study art. But he ended up at Harvard Law School and, returning to New Haven to practice his profession, bought a home in Madison. In 1960, he accepted the job of town counsel at a yearly stipend of $1,000. There were no lawsuits pending at the time and Madison's population was just over 4,000. After 35 years, and considerable sketching at town events, Mr. Costello, a Republican who served in the State Senate from 1972 to 1974, and who had the unusual distinction of being reappointed town counsel even in Democratic administrations, has retired. Recently he reminisced about his career, changes in the law and the way those changes have shaped Madison and other small towns. Following are some excerpts from that conversation.

lead_paragraph: Route 1 can seem unnaturally quiet as it runs from the Connecticut River toward the suburbs of New Haven, where it becomes synonymous with sprawl. Here it is still a single lane in each direction; traffic lights are few; and where clam shacks and marinas don't dominate, the roadside belongs to graceful old houses. Along this stretch of Route 1, when someone observes of a neighboring town, "It's in sort of a time warp," it might or might not be a compliment, depending on which century is meant, and which is preferred.

lead_paragraph: Broadway, Manhattan's crooked spine, is an urban planner's worst nightmare, foiling the city's near-perfect grid system. As this former cow path runs diagonally up the island, hopelessly tangled intersections like Herald Square, Union Square and Columbus Circle are left in its wake. And at Madison Square, woe to the hapless pedestrian who tries crossing Broadway at 23d Street in a single bound. Stretching 180 feet from curb to curb, the intersection along the north side of 23d Street is three times the normal width of an avenue, and many of those who insist on crossing without pause end up dodging a sea of oncoming cars. In just one two-year period -- from 1993 to 1995 -- at least 91 accidents involving cars, pedestrians and bicycles occurred at Madison Square, where Fifth Avenue, Broadway and four crosstown streets spill into one another.

lead_paragraph: NEW YORK LIFE employees will clean up Madison Square Park on Thursday; Staten Islanders will ''paint out'' graffiti in the area around the ferry terminal tomorrow. They are just a few of the thousands of New Yorkers who are expected to pitch in on Neighborhood Week around the city this week. Organized by the Citizens Commmittee for New York City and the Mayor's office, this volunteer effort is ''led by everyday New Yorkers'' and is an ''opportunity for people to make a change in their neighborhoods,'' said Stacey Sherman, director of Neighborhood Week. Among the many activities planned are the cleanup of the baseball field on 101st Street between First and Second Avenues in East Harlem on Saturday. And the Hoops for Peace Basketball Tournament will be played today and next Sunday in Alfred E. Smith Park on the Lower East Side. (A participant in last year's basketball event is shown at right.) And on Friday afternoon, 1,000 young people from around the city are to gather at the Central Park Summerstage to take a ''peace pledge'' at an anti-violence rally. Second Annual Neighborhood Week, today through next Sunday; free; a schedule can be obtained by calling, (212) 989-0909.

lead_paragraph: A Paterson, N.J., woman was charged with leaving her 7-year-old son alone in Madison Square Park in Manhattan for at least two hours yesterday while she worked at a photography studio 16 blocks away, the police said. The woman, a Russian immigrant, told the police that she did not know she had done anything wrong. The mother, Tatiana Glotova, 25, was arrested after returning to the park and finding her son, Dennis, talking to a police officer. The officer, Robert Cordice, said he was alerted to the situation by a group of women who noticed that the boy was alone for at least two hours at the park, at Madison Avenue and East 23d Street.

Danny Meyer, co-owner of Gramercy Tavern and Union Square Cafe, signed a 20-year lease yesterday for 21,057 square feet of space at 11 Madison Avenue, from 24th Street to 25th Street. The building, one of two block-long office towers owned by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, is now almost fully rented to tenants like the Credit Suisse First Boston Corporation, Price Waterhouse and Emanuel/Emanuel Ungaro. The other building, One Madison Avenue, will remain the corporate headquarters for Met Life. Eleven Madison Avenue, which was built in stages from 1929 to 1950, is on the National Register of Historic Places.

lead_paragraph: ''Bright Lucifer,'' a lost play written by Orson Welles in his youth, gets a world premiere next weekend in Madison, Wis. ''Lost'' may be a stretch -- scholars have known about the drama for years, but ignored it. Welles planned to produce the play but abandoned that idea when Hollywood beckoned after his 1938 radio broadcast of ''The War of the Worlds.'' Set in northern Wisconsin, the play features a newspaperman and an actor debating big questions, a la: ''Thicker and quicker flows the force and tide of evil . . . wickedness whelms over good.'' It's hardly great art, but Jay Rath -- the play's producer and a local writer and part-time butcher -- figures true fans will give it some slack. ''Welles was working on this when he was 23, 11 years younger than I am now,'' he says. ''When you think about it, it's a bit frightening.''

The Rose City Classic is the highlight of the Drew basketball season, but it may not be what you think. When the college basketball teams you see on television assemble for showcase tournaments, arenas like Continental or Madison Square Garden teem with thousands of fans, competing brass bands, gaggles of reporters, a healthy collection of National Basketball Association scouts, celebrities and student rooting sections that seem the size of oceans.

lead_paragraph: Missoni, the Milan-based women's fashion designer, is moving its Manhattan store up Madison Avenue from 69th to 78th Street, leaping over an invisible barrier that has kept the pinnacle of Madison haute couture south of 72d Street. And with annual retail rents on Madison below 72d rising to $400 a square foot, many real estate professionals believe more high-fashion boutiques will follow Missoni to its new neighborhood, where the rent is about half. ''Missoni's move opens up a no man's land,'' said Caroline Banker, a broker with New Spectrum Realty, a retail brokerage concern. ''Everybody's been waiting for someone big to do it. It was clear it was going to happen. There were too many wonderful retail spaces available. It's a fallacy that things die above 72d Street.''

Hundreds of passers-by gawked while firefighters and construction workers struggled to lower the gently swaying platform and overloaded net.

A portion of the brick facade peeled off on Sunday, raining debris on holiday shoppers and spilling a ton of bricks into a torn safety net. Yesterday, part of the repair work was completed when work crews managed to remove the safety net by using a 417-foot-high crane, the biggest one in New York City.

In anticipation of opening the whole avenue, a swath of scaffolding was also erected to shield vehicles and pedestrians.

lead_paragraph: When loose bricks from a nearby office tower pelted the roof of his Madison Avenue apartment building on Sunday afternoon, Tim Curran didn't have time to collect many of his belongings during the evacuation. He left behind his wallet. His credit cards. His appointment book. His jacket. And his cat. Yesterday, five days day after the accident, Mr. Curran was still living out of a hotel, forbidden to return to his fourth-floor apartment because of the danger of falling debris. And Mr. Curran's tabby was still trapped in the apartment at 536 Madison.

lead_paragraph: For the first time since a ton of bricks came down and closed a glitzy block on Madison Avenue last Sunday, Nicholas Cyprus got a glimpse inside his Burger Heaven restaurant yesterday. It was as dark as a cave, and he went in with a flashlight and found a scene frozen in time: something from ''The Twilight Zone.'' Rotting hamburgers. Stale bread. Half-eaten sandwiches and french fries. Overturned coffee cups. Empty soda glasses. It was all there, just as 140 patrons and a dozen workers had left it when firefighters hurriedly evacuated everybody a week ago from the place at 536 Madison Avenue, near 54th Street.

The closing is sure to bring new traffic headaches in a prime retail district as the holiday season reaches its peak. Two car lanes will be shut down and only buses will be allowed through a makeshift tunnel between 54th and 55th Streets, at least through today.

lead_paragraph: New York's top building official said yesterday that shoddy workmanship was to blame for the bricks that tumbled from a Madison Avenue office tower more than a week ago, and that the street would remain closed for at least four more days as workers gingerly remove bricks from the defective wall. Gaston Silva, the city's Building Commissioner, said the builder of 540 Madison, at 55th Street, failed to install some inexpensive pieces of metal intended to bind the facade to the building's internal frame. Over time, the bricks in some areas fell out of alignment on the south facade, spilling onto the street below.

lead_paragraph: New Yorkers live out their lives under towers of brick and concrete, walking and sitting and playing next to buildings so tall that even a tiny object plummeting from their heights could maim or kill a human strolling at ground level. It is a wonder, really, that so few tragedies occur beneath the soaring, sometimes aging skyscrapers. But the shower of bricks that fell from the side of a 39-story office tower on Madison Avenue this month reminds the city's inhabitants of their vulnerability. The building appears to have been constructed with remarkable shoddiness. The simple metal ties routinely used to bind brick facades to the building frames are missing in many places. While workmen were fixing a side wall, a section peeled off, raining two-pound bricks and debris.

lead_paragraph: WHEN scores of two-pound bricks broke loose from a 34th-floor wall of a Madison Avenue office tower earlier this month, some punched holes in the roofs of adjoining buildings while others crashed and shattered, raining concrete shrapnel onto the street below. The rest remained suspended in a safety net overhead -- an eerie tableau that showed a weakness in Local Law 10. The law, enacted in 1980 a year after a Barnard College student was killed by falling masonry near the Columbia campus, was designed to prevent such disasters. It requires owners of New York City buildings greater than six stories in height to have facades within 25 feet of a street line or public area inspected for structural soundness every five years.

lead_paragraph: ONE picture, as the saying goes, is worth a thousand words. But when it comes to music, neither pictures nor words drive the story because 1,000 of either cannot convey a single note. Photos, telling though they may be about skin color, image and attendant assumption of privilege, have no worth at all in defining the art of powerfully distinctive pianists. Two dissimilar approaches to repertory and music making are about to be revealed in solo recitals: Awadagin Pratt's this afternoon in Newark, to be repeated tomorrow in Princeton, and Earl Wild's next week in Madison.

lead_paragraph: I'M affectionate, loyal and a touch sentimental, but I have no flair for romance, which explains why I was a bit worried last spring as my 10th wedding anniversary approached. We had agreed to celebrate with an overnight getaway from Chicago and our three small children, but it was my job to choose the spot and I fretted that my wife, Michele, would be disappointed. My anxiety grew when I discovered that my first choice, the historic lodge at the scenic Starved Rock State Park on the Illinois River, was fully booked through winter. Fortunately, I had a safe backup less than a three hours' drive away, in Madison, Wis.: a combination bookstore, cafe and inn called the Canterbury. We had enjoyed a brief stop at the cafe and bookstore a year before when our family passed through town. And I figured that the inn, with each room lavishly painted to celebrate a different chapter of Chaucer's ''Canterbury Tales,'' would provide a mix of bawdiness and whimsy appropriate to a happy decade of marriage.

lead_paragraph: A skyscraper in midtown Manhattan rains debris on the buildings and streets below. Emergency workers evacuate residents and divert traffic as public officials promise action and the news media switch into high gear. Construction crews wrap the building with protective netting. This, of course, is a summary of recent events at the Conde Nast building in Times Square, in which a temporary elevator tower collapsed, dumping tons of steel and killing one person. It is also what occurred in December at 540 Madison Avenue, near 55th Street, when a ton of bricks peeled off the building's facade, injuring two people and bringing life on the block to a screeching halt.

lead_paragraph: When I come into New York these days, it's usually from Connecticut, by way of Grand Central. The terminal's newly restored ceiling, which played a crucial part in one of my novels, delights the eye, but its sudden absence of grime brings to mind not so much the ceiling's Beaux-Arts infancy as the spanking prosperity of 1998. Once arrived, I'm off to the Madison Avenue building of Conde Nast, whose magazines will soon move to a Disneyfied Times Square; or to the New York Public Library, where even the lions have been wearing hard hats; or down to the Strand bookstore, two blocks south of Union Square, whose continuing glamorization would give an anarchist spasms. But every so often I need to go see my paperback publisher in the Flatiron Building, situated where Fifth Avenue meets Broadway. Those last five words sound like a marketer's dream slogan, a one-two punch of wealth and dazzle, but they also define an actual crossroads, the nexus that occurs at 23d Street, these days a relatively humble haven in a city undergoing too much gleaming renovation.

lead_paragraph: For New York City taxi passengers, a ride in a cab is often a solitary experience and sometimes a pricey one. But in Madison, Wis., the Badger Cab Company offers a fairly affordable way to get to point B, along with company in the back seat. Since its founding 52 years ago, Badger, named after the state animal, has shunned meters in lieu of a shared-ride system. A Badger passenger may share the cab with as many as four other riders, and a few packages.

lead_paragraph: IN retailing, the young, the trendy and the new have tended to go downtown, to TriBeCa, SoHo and Chelsea. So, it's nice to see new life appearing this season on Madison Avenue, especially that stretch between 72d and 86th Streets. Madison Avenue, with its art galleries, luxury jewelry stores and designer clothiers, is a street of dreams, for both customer and retailer. But between 57th and 72d Streets, it is too pricey for most except big names like Crate and Barrel, Polo Ralph Lauren and Armani. And until recently, Madison between 72d and 86th Streets had as many as 20 vacant storefronts and few takers. Pottery Barn, where are you? Not on Madison.

lead_paragraph: ECHOES of the commercial development that swept through suburban Fairfield County in the 1970's are reverberating eastward along the midshore suburbs of New Haven County. In quiet, upscale, residential towns like Guilford, Madison and Killingworth -- where antique homes abound, a few farms still exist and village greens remain pristine -- office building and applications for new construction are accelerating despite local concerns for preserving the New England character. Cautiously, local officials have been approving construction of commercial buildings up to 50,000 square feet in communities where offices have been accommodated mostly by converting single-family homes. Small as the new structures are compared with those in Stamford, White Plains and New York, they loom large on such semi- rural horizons, and apprehension over their proliferation has nudged some local planning and zoning departments into re-examining their regulations.

It's friendly, he said. Accommodating. That afternoon, he said, he and his girlfriend were walking along State Street, the main thoroughfare connecting the University of Wisconsin campus and the State Capitol. ''We met a nice gentleman,'' Mr. Lovett said in his familiar deadpan. ''And he agreed to stop reciting a poem to us for five bucks.''

lead_paragraph: As the holiday shopping marathon begins today, bells are ringing on Madison Avenue. There are Christmas chimes, of course, and the jingle of cash registers (or at least the whisper of platinum plastic). But the peal most audible to store owners and real estate agents is of celebration, tinged ever so slightly with alarm. Madison Avenue between 57th Street and 72d Street has just been officially declared the most expensive stretch of shopping space in New York, in the country and in the world. To rent one square foot of space there costs an average of $550 a year, according to a survey by Cushman & Wakefield, the big international real estate firm.

lead_paragraph: As a vibrant center for space and technology research, this city in northern Alabama owes much of its character to an immigrant, Wernher van Braun, the German rocket scientist who helped create the Marshall Space Flight Center here after World War II. Proud of its international heritage, the city greets visitors today with flapping roadside banners that welcome newcomers in a variety of languages. But in recent years, a number of Hispanic and Asian immigrants have found that Huntsville's hospitality vanishes at the door of the Madison County tax assessor, Wayland H. Cooley. Part of Mr. Cooley's job is to grant legally authorized property tax breaks to residents who own and occupy their houses. And in several instances, according to a lawsuit scheduled for an initial hearing next week, Mr. Cooley has denied those breaks to homeowners who cannot speak English.

headline.main: Don't Speak English? No Tax Break, Alabama Official Declares

lead_paragraph: IN the era of malls and multiplexes, the opening of a new movie theater is about as noteworthy as another blade of grass in a lawn. But in Madison, the truly unique has happened. For the first time that anyone can remember, a new independent movie theater has opened for business. The Madison Art Cinemas, a dedicated art house located downtown on the Boston Post Road, opened last month and has since shown such movies as ''A Midsummer Nights Dream,'' ''The Winslow Boy'' and ''Hilary and Jackie.''

lead_paragraph: THE members of my family who live in Madison, Wis., are always a little amused when I come to their town for a visit. Inevitably I announce my arrival from a pay phone at the University of Wisconsin Memorial Union, a place they feel I should have outgrown since I was an undergraduate here a decade ago. But the Union, the hub of the university's -- and probably even the city's -- social life, is the best place I know to find out what is happening in this town that counts 40,000 students among its 200,000 inhabitants. Those students come from everywhere, which means that for a rather small town, Madison is pretty cosmopolitan, especially in its offerings of restaurants and cultural events. The university pushes Madison's boundaries, but I think the unusual geography partly explains the healthful and easygoing pace many people associate with this place.

lead_paragraph: When protests erupt over news gathering, the usual complaint is that someone printed fiction instead of fact, rumor rather than truth. But not here. In this boutique-size town, where stone fences and woods surround large homes on Connecticut's southern shore, halfway between Manhattan and Providence, R.I., residents are condemning the local newspaper for publishing what they believe is an overkill of truth. For the last three weeks, petitions have been circulating here and in a neighboring town, Guilford, calling on the local government to force The Shore Line Times, a small 123-year-old paper published twice weekly, to stop printing its police blotter. The blotter, which starts on Page 2, provides the name, age, address and alleged offense of everyone arrested in Madison and Guilford in the previous week.

lead_paragraph: Karl Marx spent all those years dreaming about the worker's paradise. Yet he never got to sit in the conference room at Berbee Information Networks Corporation and listen to Jim Berbee rattle off all the luscious perks he offers his employees. They get stock options, of course, but also Palm Pilots, cell phones and a $1,000 bonus to help with the down payment on their first homes. If they want to work in their pajamas, the company pays to install and maintain high-speed I.S.D.N. lines in their bedrooms. Two years ago Berbee took everybody in the company and their families to Disney World. Bagels and muffins are free on Fridays, the sodas in the office machine are free all the time (consumption went up 400 percent after that change), and if employees want to use the office copiers for personal use, no problem. An auto-repair service comes to the employee parking lot every other Wednesday to do oil changes and tire rotations. There's dry-cleaning delivery four days a week and pizza at least once a month (which for some reason employees still have to pay for). Marx would have looked at all the cushy benefits and figured that the dictatorship of the proletariat had finally come to pass. But there's a simpler explanation. Full employment. Berbee is located in Madison, Wis., which has a microscopic 1.2 percent unemployment rate, second lowest in the country after another university town, Columbia, Mo. Jim Berbee is desperate to attract and retain workers. He has 220 employees and an amazing 94 percent retention rate, but his company is growing so fast he also has 110 job openings. ''We're losing ground every week,'' he cries.

lead_paragraph: WHO doesn't like garlic?'' Marc Corello said when asked about the crowd at his Garlic Rose Bistro. No one there, I hope, because the menu is practically all-garlic, from soup to ice cream. The hanging bulbs of garlic remind you where you are, not that a diner could possibly forget once the Garlic Rose bread dip arrives. Its contents are considered a secret confined to a few staff members, but basically it is chunky, green, oily and addictive, with pecorino Romano shavings, fresh herbs, olive oil and plenty of garlic. At any other restaurant you might decide this is enough garlic for one night. Here, the intense dip is a way of saying there's no turning back. In any event, this concoction appeared throughout the meal, spread on croutons and baked, mixed with lamb into bulging stuffed mushrooms, and used as a marinade for the filet mignon. You can purchase a pint of it as you pay for your meal (the check notes than you can peel garlic in lieu of payment).

lead_paragraph: As a devout tea drinker, I was delighted to read Patricia Brooks's piece ''In Search of Serious Tea'' (Feb. 6). But I was disappointed that she did not include my favorite Connecticut tearoom, The Front Parlor at The British Shoppe in Madison, where a traditional English-style afternoon tea is served complete with tea sandwiches, tea cakes and a good selection of loose teas. Situated in a charming 17th-century house, the cozy tearoom also serves lunch. Selections might include a plowman's platter, soup, sandwiches or other house-made specialties such as a luscious Stilton cheese and pear tart. A large selection of teas and British food, including a good assortment of English cheeses, is available in the shop, which is run by a welcoming British couple. NANCY CRIDER Bridgewater

Wind farms have already sprung up in the Midwest, California and other places with open spaces and strong breezes, but most of them have been built by utilities, with the construction costs passed along in electric bills.

lead_paragraph: THE school district of Madison, Wis., thought it could have its Coke and drink it, too. In 1997, Madison became a pioneer of sorts, signing a contract that gave Coca-Cola exclusive rights to supply all the district's soda vending machines. The idea was to collect the cash that Coca-Cola was dangling -- a $100,000 signing bonus, plus about $500,000 over the life of the three-year contract -- without yielding to crass commercialism. Madison, the first large school district to sign an exclusive vending contract, thought it could do so without compromising its educational mission.

lead_paragraph: Rock-Tenn, a maker of boxes for consumer products, said yesterday that it would close its folding-carton plant in Madison, Wis., and dismiss as many as 200 employees, or 2.4 percent of its work force, because business in the Midwest has slowed. Rock-Tenn will cut 80 to 100 jobs the next 30 to 60 days and 100 more the next six months, a spokesman said. The company has about 8,500 employees and operates 20 United States plants. Rock-Tenn. based in Norcross. Ga., will take a charge of about $1.3 million, or about 4 cents a share, to close the plant. Shares of Rock-Tenn rose 18.75 cents, to $9.875, on the New York Stock Exchange. (Bloomberg News)

lead_paragraph: Store windows, each a fantasy world, are ways to seduce the public into entering the shop's inner sanctum and seeking personal fulfillment by buying the fashionable products on view. Unlike the flat world of magazine advertising, the three-dimensional store window, with life-size mannequins and realistic props, has functioned over the years as a small, though frozen, performance space in which passers-by can imagine themselves as players. As an inveterate pedestrian along Madison Avenue from 57th to 86th Streets, I have been monitoring and shopping these windows for years. Lately I have been bemoaning the clinical look of stores like Giorgio Armani, at 65th Street, which strip down their displays to a minimalist modernism of dressed torsos, with not so much as a gesturing hand to suggest personality.

lead_paragraph: 'The Influence Machine' Art in the Park Madison Avenue at 26th Street Through Tuesday It's all or nothing with Tony Oursler's installation at Madison Square Park. Mr. Oursler's ''Influence Machine'' -- four large-scale video projections and a sound piece involving a street lamp -- must be seen as part of a larger whole, a Fellini-esque installation-cum-happening that also includes the rubble of the partly renovated park, the golden-crowned skyscrapers nearby, the dark silhouettes of the people tending the work's array of technical equipment and the milling passers-by and dog-walkers who chat with one another or on cell phones while watching the various effects metamorphose before their eyes.
