lead_paragraph: Four years ago, Madison Square Park in Manhattan was woefully run-down, with broken benches and a dust bowl of a lawn. Today, when the park reopens after four years of renovations, the historic fountain off East 23rd Street will again spurt water and a new reflecting pond will shimmer on the park's opposite end. The six-acre, 19th-century square has been planted with 15,000 shrubs, flowering plants and trees. The project was spearheaded by the City Parks Foundation, a nonprofit organization that raises private money for New York City parks. It cost $12 million, most of which was contributed by corporations whose offices overlook the park.

lead_paragraph: With great fanfare, Madison Square Park reopened yesterday, offering a quiet and elegant refuge in Manhattan's bustling Midtown. The facelift for this 19th-century oasis is a credit to civic-minded neighbors and corporations, which raised enough money and pushed enough of the right levers for a quick and thorough restoration of the six-acre park near the old Flatiron Building. But the revival of Madison Square is also a vivid reminder of the shabby state of many of the public parks elsewhere in New York City. The restoration of these vital public spaces is an issue that ought to rank much higher on the agenda of every mayoral candidate. The percentage of the city budget spent on the maintenance and operation of the city's 1,700 parks has dropped dramatically over the last 15 years. Private donations have grown, but two-thirds of these have gone to two parks in Manhattan, Central Park and Bryant Park. For those parks without angels, the city has been an exceptionally stingy custodian. After years of cuts, there is now only one park worker for every 43 acres of parkland, one gardener for every 1,000 acres. Since 1970, full-time park staff has been reduced by two-thirds.

The popcorn is seasoned with sage, rosemary and garlic; the iced tea is brewed of leaves from T Salon. The Chipwich knockoff has coffee ice cream in the center, and the brownies are moist with coconut.

lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Is it insecurity that so often leads New Yorkers down the perilous path of hyperbolic overstatement? It was with amusement that I read Regina Schrambling's assertion (''Trees vs. Produce: Clashing Greens in Union Square,'' June 6) that ''Manhattan simply has the best farmers' market in the United States.'' Ms. Schrambling should visit the Farmers' Market in Madison, Wis., where each Saturday from April through October some 13,000 to 18,000 epicureans convene to sample the bounty of the surrounding countryside. All this beneath a circular canopy of oak trees, set against the backdrop of the majestic State Capitol.

lead_paragraph: JAMES MADISON HIGH SCHOOL was built 75 years ago to serve the growing families of the surrounding area when much of the farmland there was giving way to urbanization. The resulting rectangular blocks would end up almost exclusively residential, some of them featuring the spacious Spanish-style terrace homes for which the area is known. The high school's namesake neighborhood, though, was not commonly called Madison until a decade ago. It had been considered a part of Marine Park and, before that, of Sheepshead Bay. This small area, bounded by commercial thoroughfares and without a subway stop of its own, is still unknown to many.

lead_paragraph: The Madison school board has been swamped with e-mail messages and phone calls after barring the recital of the Pledge of Allegiance in the district's schools and deciding that ''The Star-Spangled Banner'' should be played without its martial lyrics. Bill Keys, a school board member, said it was simply trying to comply with a new state law protecting the rights of students who did not want to feel compelled to recite their loyalty to ''one nation, under God.'' Parents and others have denounced the 3-to-2 vote, taken Monday, as unpatriotic, especially with the country at war against terrorism. Calvin Williams, the board's president, has said it will reconsider its decision at a meeting next week.

lead_paragraph: Gov. George E. Pataki has brokered a tentative deal with the Oneida Indian Nation that, if ratified by the New York State Legislature and Congress, could resolve a bitter 31-year-old dispute over a quarter-million acres the Oneidas maintain the state bought from them illegally through treaties in the 19th century. Under the agreement, the state and federal governments would pay three branches of the tribe $500 million and the tribe would drop its claim to most of the land. Tribal leaders would use part of the money to buy back about 35,000 acres from willing sellers in Madison and Oneida Counties, with about 5,000 acres set aside as wilderness. The land would not be contiguous, and the current owners would not be forced to give up their property.

headline.main: Pataki Works Out Deal With Indians For Upstate Land

lead_paragraph: A day after Gov. George E. Pataki announced a tentative land settlement with Oneida Indians in New York, Wisconsin leaders of the tribe said yesterday that the agreement was meaningless and vowed to press on with their lawsuit, which seeks the restoration of 270,000 acres to the tribe. The governor's proposed solution also provoked a mixed response among landowners in Oneida and Madison Counties, who have lived with the Oneidas' lawsuit hanging over them for 30 years. Many said the proposed settlement did not resolve the most important issues for local businesses, farmers and homeowners, since the tribe would still not collect state and county sales taxes at their lucrative casino and other businesses. As a sovereign nation, the Oneidas do not pay property or school taxes either.

lead_paragraph: Just five days after Gov. George E. Pataki trumpeted a tentative agreement with the Oneida Indians of New York State to end a 31-year-old dispute over a quarter of a million acres in Central New York, the deal has begun to unravel. The Oneidas of Wisconsin, a separate branch of the tribe that was shut out of the negotiations, filed 20 lawsuits today against individual landowners in Oneida and Madison counties. In essence, the move makes private citizens bargaining chips in the struggle over the tribe's claim that the state illegally bought its land 200 years ago. The lawsuits have been filed against owners of commercial, agricultural, entertainment and abandoned properties, but no residential property owners.

lead_paragraph: The volunteers and staff at St. Bernard's Catholic Church sat around the living room in the rectory after dinner on Thursday night, giggling. Should they short-sheet Father Mike's bed? The last time they had done so, they recalled, he had known exactly who was behind it, and confronted her, demanding with mock sternness, ''Who paid you?'' So this time, the troublemakers instead took the bendable toy Easter bunnies Father Mike was planning to give out after Sunday's services and hid them in plain sight in the kitchen: on cabinet handles, on the hanging lamp, in place of the twist-tie on the bag of bread in the refrigerator. He would know who had done it, but at least he would get a laugh. They sensed he could use it.

lead_paragraph: Thousands of people who have installed a popular wireless video camera, intending to increase the security of their homes and offices, have instead unknowingly opened a window on their activities to anyone equipped with a cheap receiver. The wireless video camera, which is heavily advertised on the Internet, is intended to send its video signal to a nearby base station, allowing it to be viewed on a computer or a television. But its signal can be intercepted from more than a quarter-mile away by off-the-shelf electronic equipment costing less than $250.

lead_paragraph: IN the language of New Jersey's bedroom communities, this town may well have the softest sheets around. Madison is an oasis of tone and comfort, of shaded parks and sidewalks, with two universities, a historic train station, bustling restaurants and an intact downtown center. It is no wonder that Geraldine Rockefeller Dodge, the dog-fancying heiress who donated the splendid municipal building here, made Madison her home and lifetime pet project.

lead_paragraph: On a typical summer evening, illegal tables and chairs spill from a smattering of small restaurants onto the sidewalks of Madison Avenue. In 1980, the city banned sidewalk cafes along Madison Avenue and in nearly four dozen other areas in the borough, along with four areas in Brooklyn and four in Queens, to accommodate pedestrian traffic. But in recent months, restaurateurs, hit by the sagging economy and decreasing tourism, have sought to overturn the 1980 prohibitions and make it easier to apply for a license to operate a sidewalk cafe, which can take more than a year.

lead_paragraph: EVERY year at this time, members of the Suquamish nation set up temporary roadside stands and transform the Port Madison reservation, just outside Seattle, into a bustling, booming market for fireworks. As throngs of mostly white customers descend upon the American Indian reservation to load up on rockets and sparklers for Independence Day celebrations, the air is filled with bartering, cross-cultural exchanges and, most of all, explosions. Both the big bangs and the more pensive moments of a Fourth of July weekend on the Port Madison reservation are the subjects of ''Boomtown,'' which has its premiere Tuesday at 10 p.m. on PBS. The second program in the current 15th-anniversary season of the PBS documentary series ''P.O.V.,'' ''Boomtown'' is characteristic of this series's tendency to delve into subcultures and subject material rarely covered on television, and to do so in a manner that retains the quirky ''point of view'' style of independent filmmaking.

lead_paragraph: Welcome When Bartolomé Esteban Murillo was 15, he prepared a will in anticipation of a voyage to America. By all accounts, though, Murillo never ventured far from his native Seville in his lifetime, but the full range of his art has found a welcome home in the United States. Beginning on Sunday, more than 30 of his paintings from the golden age of Spanish art, assembled from American museums and private collections, will be exhibited through Oct. 6 at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art. Described as the first comprehensive retrospective devoted to the artist, ''Bartolomé Esteban Murillo (1617-1682): Paintings From American Collections'' was organized by the museum and the Kimbell Art Museum in Fort Worth. Calling All Citoyens There will be dancing in the street on Sunday. That's because Sunday is Bastille Day, and in New York the seventh annual Bastille Day on 60th Street celebration, commemorating the storming of the prison in Paris in 1789, will bring festivities to the stretch between Madison and Park Avenues. Presented by the French Institute Alliance Française from noon to 6 p.m., the event includes music, the traditional bal musette (dancing in the street), races, arts and crafts for children, French food and a singing of ''La Marseillaise.''

lead_paragraph: AFTER Sept. 11, R. J. Julia Booksellers, which takes up 6,000 square feet in two buildings in Madison, a town of 16,000, became a kind of town square where people could share their shock. The store brought in authors like former Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott, the Yale historian Paul Kennedy and Karen Armstrong, author of ''The History of God,'' for lectures and discussions that helped residents make sense of what had happened. It was a predictable response from R. J. Julia, to which more than 200 authors come each year for lectures, readings and book signings. ''I want the store to be a place where conversation matters,'' said Roxanne Coady, the owner. And it is revealing of the character of Madison that the events were jammed. (Ms. Armstrong's visit had to be moved to the high school.)

lead_paragraph: About a decade ago (no one knows for sure) someone stole the sword from the bronze statue of Adm. David G. Farragut in Madison Square Park in the Flatiron District. The statue, considered by some to be one of the city's most important pieces of public art, is a 1930's replica of the 1881 original by Augustus Saint-Gaudens. Last week another sword was returned to the admiral's hilt as part of a privately financed $30,000 restoration. A ceremony was held at the base of the statue, and a retired admiral spoke. He disputed that Admiral Farragut ever said, ''Full speed ahead!'' after declaring, ''Damn the torpedoes!'' at the Battle of New Orleans in 1862.

lead_paragraph: Law enforcement authorities in New York City and New Jersey said yesterday that they had seized about $61 million worth of cocaine and arrested five members of a Mexican drug gang that used a house on a quiet suburban block in Madison, N.J., to store drugs. The seizure, described as the largest in Morris County, followed a lengthy investigation by the police on both sides of the Hudson River. It evolved in part from Operation Crack Down, in which the New York City police have focused on drug trafficking in Washington Heights and Upper Manhattan, forcing dealers and distributors to other bases of operation.

lead_paragraph: LINED with Colonial homes, white churches, antique shops and rustic red barns, Woodbury's Main Street is the picture of historic New England preservation. Perfect, some say, until you get to the statue of the golden naked lady with arms and legs outstretched, the 20-foot-tall, four-legged orange creature made of steel, or the big black and white metal structure. These pieces might be considered art anywhere else, but in Woodbury, some town officials want them out, saying they are ruining the rustic integrity of the town's historic district, one the town has nurtured.

headline.main: Get That Sculpture Off Your Lawn!

lead_paragraph: Week after week, Linda Wilmoth and hundreds of other workers have taken turns picketing outside the truck factory just north of Old Hickory Boulevard, burning cords of wood through a brutal winter. The workers are delighted about the arrival of spring, but they continue to rage against their company, Peterbilt Motors, which locked them out right after Labor Day, warning that it would not let them return to work until they accepted management's contract offer.

lead_paragraph: A recent $10 billion Illinois court judgment against Philip Morris is threatening to disrupt payments from the 1998 tobacco settlement between 46 states and the tobacco industry, Washington's attorney general said. Philip Morris, a unit of Altria, has told the states it cannot post the $12 billion appeal bond required by the Madison County, Ill., court and pay the $2.6 billion it owes the states next month. The attorney general, Christine O. Gregoire, who negotiated the 1998 settlement, said that if the issue was not resolved soon, she and other attorneys general would seek to intervene in Illinois to reduce the appeal bond.

lead_paragraph: THE Connecticut waterfront east of the New Haven area used to be considered far enough away from New York that even the middle class could afford a house around the water. Not any more. Five years ago, prices started going up, and two years ago the increases became meteoric. Buyers are willing to pay double and triple the appraisal amounts of only a few years ago. This, of course, has not gone unnoticed by tax assessors, who have used revaluations to increase property taxes along the shoreline to reflect the skyrocketing values. It is an old story in such areas as Fairfield County, but one that now has waterfront homeowners from Branford to Stonington complaining that their new assessments are unfair and some longtime residents saying they can no longer afford to live in their homes.

headline.main: Look at the View. Look at the Taxes.

lead_paragraph: The principal of a Catholic high school was arrested yesterday and charged with criminal sexual contact and endangering the welfare of a child, the Morris County prosecutor's office said. The principal, Frank D. Mattiace, 66, of Montville, was arrested at Bayley-Ellard High School in Madison, said Lt. Jeffrey S. Paul of the prosecutor's office. The victim, a 17-year-old boy, complained to his parents about the principal's behavior, and they contacted the Madison police, said Lieutenant Paul, declining to elaborate on the charges. Mr. Mattiace was released after posting $50,000 bail, Lieutenant Paul said. He was forbidden to have contact with the victim and to have any unsupervised contact with children under 18. A message left at Mr. Mattiace's home was not answered last night. Msgr. James L. Fallon, the school's chaplain, said the principal intended to continue in his position. Tina Kelley (NYT)

lead_paragraph: The important thing about Madison Avenue has always been that it lies between Fifth and Park. Fifth Avenue is and has long been the most fashionable address in Manhattan, with all those mansion-size apartments and terraces overlooking Central Park. If it was good enough for Jacqueline Onassis, it's good enough for us. Park Avenue, whose name long ago became synonymous with high-priced elegance, is an almost equally grand boulevard, its medians planted year-round with tulips, daffodils, lighted Christmas trees, depending on the season. Strolling up Madison, you'll see several real estate brokers with photographs of offerings in the neighborhood. The least expensive thing I saw there on a recent walk was a one-bedroom on 84th Street for just under $1 million. Here a $5-million apartment is no big deal.

lead_paragraph: ON an isthmus sandwiched by Lakes Mendota and Monona, Madison, the capital of Wisconsin, is a progressive university town noted for the good life: sailing, paddling and windsurfing in the summer; cross-country skiing, hiking and ice-skating in the winter (which can be so cold, in fact, that bundled-up Madisonians take on a unisex look); good old Midwestern values all year-round. In 1948, Life magazine featured Madison as its pick for the best place to live in America; thankfully, not much has changed. It's the kind of place where you will find well-maintained (and well-used) bike paths, an abundance of locally grown organic food at the weekend farmers' market and bed-and-breakfasts with ecological and historical awareness. But don't let Madison's fresh-scrubbed face fool you -- its radical 1960's past may have mellowed into more of a fervor for football, but it is all balanced with a sophisticated cultural life comparable to that of a much larger city. Frank Lloyd Wright buildings dot the landscape, and thriving theater and arts communities can be found on and off campus, along with a competitive culinary scene and a diverse population that includes punk-rock students and die-hard conservatives. What could be finer? BONNIE TSUI Friday 5 p.m. 1) A Campus Tour The pedestrian-only State Street runs from the University of Wisconsin-Madison campus to the Capitol, connecting the academic center to the seat of government. Strolling the avenue is an ideal way to get the lay of the land and an idea of how eclectic this town really is: you will see the progression of businesses from crunchy coffee bars, record shops and thrift stores to upscale bars, restaurants and brew pubs. The bars get busy on football weekends. And the campus stadium is filled with fans who come back weekend after weekend to cheer the Badgers. Start your journey off right with some of the richest ice cream you will ever have -- made by the university's dairy students from the agriculture school -- at the Memorial Union (800 Langdon Street, 608-265-3000). A Friday evening on the union's terrace, complete with live music, bratwurst and $3 beers, can't be beat.

lead_paragraph: Average asking rents have risen for retail space in Manhattan in the last year, most sharply in prime shopping corridors like Fifth Avenue, Madison Avenue and 57th Street. The greatest demand came from small tenants looking for stores with less than 10,000 square feet of space, according to a study by the Real Estate Board of New York to be released this week. But 16 deals for larger blocks were also done; the biggest among them was Home Depot's lease for 108,000 square feet at 28-40 West 23rd Street.

lead_paragraph: The Rayovac Corporation, the battery maker, said that it would consolidate the operations of Remington Products, the razor business it acquired in September, lay off 217 workers and move its own headquarters to Atlanta from Madison, Wis. Remington's offices and a plant in Bridgeport, Conn., will be shut and combined with Rayovac in Wisconsin beginning in March, Rayovac said. Rayovac is also shutting 65 remaining Remington service centers by next month. Rayovac will have costs of at least $8 million this year to integrate Remington; the company expects eventual annual savings of as much as $35 million. About 25 positions, including Rayovac's executive management, will move to Atlanta, which was chosen because it is closer to important global customers, the company said.

lead_paragraph: Three years after the once desolate Madison Square Park was extensively restored, a restoration credited by real estate specialists as having helped attract tenants to nearby office and showroom spaces, the largest block of high-quality office space currently available in the area is about to come to market officially. The space soon to be available, at 51 Madison Avenue, between 26th and 27th Streets, is in the 40-story landmark gold-pinnacled tower that has been occupied mostly by the New York Life Insurance Company since 1928. New York Life plans to keep using the 925,000-square-foot building as its headquarters, according to a company spokesman, William Werfelman. It wants to lease 290,000 square feet, however, because it is diversifying its offices to a 383,000-square-foot building it bought last year in what had been the Mount Pleasant Executive Center in Sleepy Hollow, N.Y., about four miles north of the Tappan Zee bridge in Westchester County.

lead_paragraph: Mayor Dave Cieslewicz said he thought his job would be limited to deciding issues like whether to build a municipal pool in this city of 215,000 residents or add a light-rail system. Instead he finds himself in the middle of a debate over Middle East peace. A proposal for Madison to form a sister-city relationship with the Palestinian city of Rafah has divided Jews and others in this college town and prompted personal attacks and accusations of anti-Semitism. The mayor and members of the Common Council, the city council, have received scores of impassioned letters, e-mail messages and phone calls from angry constituents.

Just outside the park, at Madison Avenue and 26th Street, a 108-year-old Italianate neoclassical building that once housed the headquarters of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals has been gutted. Within its remaining four-story rusticated facade, and on seven floors to rise above it, multimillion-dollar condominiums will be built.

lead_paragraph: ON Saturday, Sept. 30, 1972, 11 produce vendors set up shop in a street near Wisconsin's majestic white granite capitol. Customers quickly exhausted their meager stocks. A week later 85 fruit and vegetable sellers turned up, their stalls filling much of Capitol Square, to be mobbed by several thousand eager consumers. Such were the modest beginnings of the Dane County Farmers' Market, now recognized as the largest in the nation by the North American Farmers' Direct Marketing Association, and still growing. This year, as the harvest in this fertile state neared a climax on Sept. 18, more than 20,000 people made their way from stall to colorful stall, from tomatoes to bison to apples to cheese, in an almost uninterrupted river of humanity. Counterclockwise along the sidewalks beneath the imposing dome they walked, towing wagons, pushing baby carriages and lugging bulging canvas or paper bags.

headline.main: A Peach . . . No, a Honey Of a Farmers' Market

snippet: The Dane County Farmers' Market in Wisconsin is now recognized as the largest in the nation, and is still growing.

lead_paragraph: The Overture Center for the Arts, a $200 million arts complex in downtown Madison, Wis., opened its doors on Sept. 18 after more than six years of construction. The center, which covers an entire city block, was designed by the architect Cesar Pelli and will showcase a wide array of entertainment, from touring Broadway shows and music concerts to nine resident arts organizations, including the Madison Symphony Orchestra, Madison Opera and Madison Ballet. Mr. Pelli's design uses existing Madison landmarks like an old department store facade and the vaudeville-era Capitol Theater building, and new, strikingly modern buildings with soaring glass walls and a glass dome above a grand rotunda. The center, on Madison's main pedestrian thoroughfare near the campus of University of Wisconsin and the state capitol, adds significantly to the small city's vibrant cultural scene, which is already comparable to that of many larger cities. It houses seven performance spaces, including the grand 2,257-seat Overture Hall and five visual-arts spaces for viewing works by local and regional artists. The center is also the new home of the Wisconsin Academy of Sciences, Arts and Letters, a leading cultural institution in the state.

headline.main: Arts Center Opens In Madison, Wis.

lead_paragraph: A single-engine plane attempting to make an emergency landing in a ball field in Madison, Conn., instead plowed into a nearby house yesterday evening, killing the two people on board, officials and neighbors said. Three residents of the home were inside at the time of the crash, but managed to escape, according to Robert Gerard, the chief of the Madison Fire Department.

headline.main: Single-Engine Plane Crashes Into House in Connecticut, Killing 2

snippet: A single-engine plane attempting to make an emergency landing in a ball field in Madison, Conn., instead plowed into a nearby house yesterday evening, killing the two people on board, officials and neighbors said.

lead_paragraph: About the only person who could eclipse Alber Elbaz last Wednesday at Barneys was the Boss. Bruce Springsteen walked into Fred's, where his wife, Patti Scialfa, was waiting with Rita Wilson, Jann Wenner and Matt Nye, and all the pretty heads did that swivel thing. In fact, there was a whole lot of bobbing going on in the past few days: over to H & M to catch the ruckus for the Karl Lagerfeld line; up to Bergdorf Goodman to see Loulou de la Falaise's spring seersucker; and on to Madison Avenue, where last night Oscar de la Renta had a party to open his first store.

headline.main: Front Row

abstract: Oscar de la Renta, who has been presence in New York for over 40 years, opens his first store, on Madison Avenue; he plans to open second boutique, in Miami, Fla, and third in Las Vegas; photos (M)
snippet: H & M's launch of its Karl Lagerfeld line, Loulou de la Falaise's spring collection at Bergdorf Goodman and Oscar de la Renta's party at his Madison Avenue store made for a busy week of fashion.

lead_paragraph: One man came from working-class roots and built a media empire that surpassed its rivals, while the other was brought into the family business and has struggled to make it succeed. When angered by aides, one rips into them privately; the other is openly incandescent, covering his subordinates with expletives for all to hear. One is a billionaire who sometimes rides the subway to his job in City Hall; the other prefers a black Mercedes stretch limousine with special license plates issued by the police. Both men get blamed for the troubles of the New York Knicks.

headline.main: A Contest of Will, Wealth and Ambition; Dispute Over Stadium Becomes Political, and Personal

abstract: Mayor Michael R Bloomberg and Cablevision chmn James Dolan are at center of most vicious battle of Bloomberg mayoralty; it pits Dolan, very rich man with enormous attachment to his legendary Madison Square Garden, against even richer mayor whose passion to leave his mark on West Side of Manhattan is rivaled only by his distaste for man trying to stop him; battle between two men over whether city should help finance football stadium for New York Jets gets nastier daily and is becoming factor in 2005 mayoral race; photo (M)
snippet: The battle between Mayor Michael Bloomberg and the head of Cablevision over whether New York should finance a football stadium for the Jets gets nastier daily.

lead_paragraph: AT the SavOn convenience store in this tiny, tidy upstate city of 3,000 or so, a gallon of regular gas goes for $1.86, a pack of Marlboros goes for $3.75, and the history goes on forever. So to understand why the United States Supreme Court will hear arguments on Tuesday in the dispute between the city and the tribe, you need to sort through enough history to make your head spin: which tribes sided with the colonists and which with Great Britain in the Revolutionary War, the relative merits of the 1788 Treaty of Fort Schuyler, the 1794 Treaty of Canandaigua and the 1838 Treaty of Buffalo Creek.

headline.main: A Land Deal, A Tax Bill And a Dispute

abstract: Our Towns column about Sherrill, New York, tiny upstate city at center of tax dispute involving Oneida Indians; tribe's land claims date to various 18th- and 19th-century treaties but immediate roots lie in casino wealth that has enabled Oneidas to buy up land across Oneida and Madison Counties and then claim exemption from local taxes as sovereign nation; Sherrill city manager David Barker says it is ridiculous for local business like SavOn convenience store to be able to choose which taxes it will pay (M)
snippet: The Oneida tribe bought land that was once part of their ancestral home and built a convenience store there. When the tax bill came, the tribe the property was exempt.

lead_paragraph: Madison's Board of the Selectmen have decided to delay a decision on whether to have a dress code for town employees. Katherine Christopher, the town's director of human resources, said the board could make a decision at a meeting Jan. 24.

lead_paragraph: AS the Daniel Hand High School football team was celebrating its state championship at the Capitol in Hartford on Wednesday, one of the boys on its playoff roster was serving a suspension for possessing steroids. Five students from Daniel Hand in Madison were arrested on Tuesday and charged with possessing steroids, according to Detective Sgt. Todd Curry. All five were arrested and suspended from school for 10 days. The school is still investigating the steroid charges and could eventually expel the students.

lead_paragraph: Madison these days has been acting like a ditzy dame in one of Shakespeare's comedies. First, it was flattered that it was being wooed by ABC to be part of a pilot for new reality television show called ''My Kind of Town.'' In fact, Madison was so smitten that its officials offered a town-owned facility for use during the casting session. ABC, for its part, indicated that it was intrigued by ''the characters'' who lived and worked in the town.

lead_paragraph: A sixth student at Daniel Hand High School was arrested on a steroid-possession charge yesterday, and school officials expelled one of the five charged earlier. The police believe some of the students brought the steroids back to school from a vacation in Mexico. Three of the other students charged are scheduled to be arraigned today in New Haven Superior Court, then face expulsion hearings before school officials later in the day. Board of Education members voted yesterday to expel one juvenile and discipline a 14-year-old. They were also referred to Juvenile Court to face charges. School officials said the students were members of Hand's football, track and baseball teams.

lead_paragraph: A former Madison police chief has been convicted of defrauding his elderly parents of their house and money. The former chief, Dennis J. Anziano, 57, pleaded no contest on Monday to one count of larceny after being accused of bilking his parents of more than $450,000 worth of cash and real estate. He was given a suspended prison sentence. Mr. Anziano's wife, Patricia, who was charged with conspiring with him, received accelerated rehabilitation, a special form of probation for first-time offenders.

lead_paragraph: A jury was chosen in this liberal bastion on Thursday for the trial of a Hmong immigrant charged with killing six hunters, causing consternation in the North Woods, where the shootings took place. Some residents of Rice Lake, where all the victims lived or grew up, said they were concerned that the jurors from Dane County, which encompasses Madison, might not grasp the nuances of rural life.

headline.main: Rural vs. City Ways at Issue in a Wisconsin Murder Trial

abstract: Jury is chosen in Madison, Wis, for trial of Chai Soua Vang, Hmong immigrant charged with killing six hunters in North Woods; some residents of Rice Lake where victims lived or grew up express concern that jurors might not grasp nuances of rural life, including culture and etiquette of hunting; concern stems in part from racial overtones of case; Vang claims hunters, who were white, swore at him, used racial slurs and shot at him first; hunter who survived says Vang shot first; jury is all white and will be sequestered during trial; Vang, who is charged with six counts of murder, faces life in prison if convicted; photo (M)
snippet: A jury was chosen in Madison for the trial of a Hmong immigrant charged with killing six hunters, causing consternation in the North Woods where the shootings took place.

lead_paragraph: A Hmong refugee charged with killing six Wisconsin hunters last fall took the stand at his trial here on Thursday, testifying that he had acted in self-defense after he was shot at and subjected to a torrent of ethnic slurs. The defendant, Chai Soua Vang, a 36-year old truck driver from St. Paul, said he had been was encircled by a seemingly unending platoon of white hunters who refused to help him off private property, yelled ethnic and obscene slurs, and shot at him first as he tried to retreat.

lead_paragraph: The billionaire hedge-fund investor Steven A. Cohen likes to keep his shopping sprees to himself. But that's pretty difficult in today's gossipy art world, especially when he recently spent more than $100 million on two well-documented paintings, one by Vincent van Gogh and the other by Paul Gauguin. When the seller is another high-profile collector -- the Las Vegas casino owner Stephen A. Wynn -- the transaction becomes all the more fascinating.

headline.main: A Gauguin And a van Gogh Change Hands

abstract: Carol Vogel Inside Art column; billionaire hedge-fund investor Steven Cohen reportedly pays more than $100 million to Las Vegas casino owner Stephen Wynn for Van Gogh's Peasant Woman Against a Background of Wheat and Gauguin's Bathers; plans are underway to expand art program at newly restored Madison Square Park to year round; works by minimalist sculptor Jene Highstein will go on view beginning October 21; New Museum of Contemporary Art will break ground on $35 million building at Bowery and Prince Street; photos (M)

lead_paragraph: EVELYN AND DON LEWIS lived through a typical suburban life cycle in the town of Ridgefield: they had children, watched them grow and watched them leave. Then, they saw younger families move in with small children. At that point, they thought it might be time to find a new place to live, in keeping with their post-child-rearing lives. ''We were looking for a neighborhood with people we could share more in common with,'' Mrs. Lewis said. They found it in Newtown in a place not far from their old neighborhood, but a world apart otherwise, because children are not allowed to live there.

lead_paragraph: The jeers, boos and insults flew, as caustic as any that angry New Yorkers have hurled inside Madison Square Garden. The objects of derision yesterday, however, were not the hapless New York Knicks, but Senator John McCain, the keynote speaker at the New School graduation, and his host, Bob Kerrey, the university president. No sooner had Mr. Kerrey welcomed the audience to the university's 70th commencement than the hoots began to rise through the Theater at Madison Square Garden. Several graduates held up a banner aimed at Mr. McCain, an Arizona Republican and likely 2008 presidential candidate, declaring: ''Our commencement is not your platform.'' Other students and faculty members waved orange fliers with the same message.

headline.main: In the Garden, Graduates Boo McCain. Kerrey, Too.

abstract: New School students boo Sen John McCain, keynote speaker at graduation ceremony at Madison Square Garden, and also university president, Bob Kerrey, for inviting McCain to speak; some students and faculty members hold up banners, turn their backs, or leave facility during McCain's speech, which was supportive of war in Iraq; photos (M)
snippet: Senator John McCain of Arizona, the keynote speaker at the New School graduation, was met with jeers, boos and insults during his speech.

lead_paragraph: FORWARD reeled the mind in jerky, five-second stop-time intervals, when it was learned that Danny Meyer had installed a Web cam on top of Shake Shack, his Madison Square Park dog-and-burger stand, so that customers, who often stand in line for an hour and a half for a Chicago dog and cheese fries, might, as the Web site notes, ''plan your time, check out the line.'' The possibilities were endless: Could a cruel employer bust an employee who had claimed a doctor's appointment? Could one actually calculate how long the wait would be by looking at an image? Was the cam a brilliant marketing move by a restaurateur whose touch is so golden (he also owns Union Square Cafe, Blue Smoke, Tabla and Eleven Madison Park) that he might be called Canny Danny Meyer? Or might the Shake Shack Cam turn out to be a handy device for spotting a criminal, turning up any moment on CSI? (''Hey, boss-- there behind the Senator Roscoe Conkling Monument -- isn't that a man stabbing someone repeatedly? No, forget it, he was just shaking ketchup on his 'Shroom burger.'')

headline.main: Nice Gesture, But Can They E-Mail a Burger?

abstract: Danny Meyer installs Web cam on top of Shake Shack, his dog-and-burger stand in Madison Square Park, so that customers at their desks can guage how long their wait might be before heading out of the office; photos (M)
snippet: Shake Shack, Danny Meyer's Madison Square Park dog-and-burger stand, has installed a Web cam for viewing the waiting line.

lead_paragraph: A PAIR of ducks sat on the muddy shore of the Neck River in Madison last Tuesday, oblivious to the environmental destruction taking place just under their feet. Vegetation in the salty marshes near Long Island Sound is dying off, putting plants and animals at risk and causing the shore to erode. Scientists call it sudden wetland dieback, but they are not sure how it started and what they can do to end it.

lead_paragraph: FOR the last 80 years or so, Samuel Sullivan ''Sunset'' Cox has stood sentinel over Tompkins Square Park, providing shade to passing pedestrians but little pause for thought. Cox served in Congress for more than 20 years, from two states, and apparently did little to distinguish himself outside of having a swell nickname and championing causes dear to the hearts of mailmen. Not long after his death in 1889, a group of post office employees collected $10,000 to have a statue made, and when it was dedicated, mailmen from as far away as New Orleans made the trip to honor their benefactor. A president served as one of his pallbearers, which is more than most of us will ever be able to say, but it seems fair to characterize Cox as the 19th-century equivalent of Paul S. Sarbanes of Maryland: a fine public servant, but statue material?

headline.main: Let Us Now Praise Sort of Famous Men

abstract: Andrew Elrick New York Observed article on monuments in Madison Square Park in Manhattan to three once-famous men--William Seward, secretary of state during Civil War, Sen Roscoe Conkling, who played critical role in 1880 election of Pres James Garfield, and Pres Chester A Arthur, who succeeded Garfield after he was assassinated; photos (M)
snippet: Once they were household names. Today, their statues stand less as memorials to their exploits than as mute proof that glory fades.

lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Something Is Killing the Marsh Grass, but No One Is Sure What It Is'' (July 2): The best explanation for the widespread dieback of salt marsh edges may be the simplest one: sea level rise. Salt marsh cordgrass is an intertidal plant (it grows at elevations between low tide and high tide). While this species receives a daily bath of seawater, it prefers the upper half of the intertidal zone, and it does not tolerate constant inundation.

lead_paragraph: IT'S time to face facts: I live on Planet Polo. Until a couple of years ago, the stretch between 71st and 72nd Streets on Madison Avenue, not far from where I live, was a pleasant retail hodgepodge of small boutiques. There was Alain Mikli, the eyeglasses purveyor, but its lease expired. The stationery store vanished, but the clerks were snooty, and I was glad to see them go. Silvano Lattanzi, bespoke shoemaker, moved up the avenue.

lead_paragraph: Standing on a stone base at the northern end of Madison Square Park, Adm. David Glasgow Farragut, immortalized in bronze, directs his stern gaze at an ever-shifting sea of sunbathers and picnickers and stroller-pushers. But for nine days next month, the Civil War leader who ordered his men to ''damn the torpedoes'' will be staring at the back of a JumboTron.

lead_paragraph: A predawn fire destroyed a century-old Elks Lodge and the former City Hall on Friday, but was doused by firefighters before it spread deeper into one of the nation's largest historic-landmark districts. Mayor Al Huntington said the 1902 Elks Lodge and an 1876 building that was the City Hall until 1994 were reduced to smoldering brick shells. It was unclear if the remains were stable enough to be saved for eventual restoration, he said.

lead_paragraph: Missing Indians Join Lichtenstein Show When the Montclair Art Museum in New Jersey and the Roy Lichtenstein Foundation first presented ''Roy Lichtenstein: American Indian Encounters'' last year, the show unexpectedly had important repercussions: four paintings and two works on paper, which the foundation either never knew existed or thought were lost, came to light. ''We got lucky,'' said Jack Cowart, executive director of the Lichtenstein Foundation, who is compiling a catalogue raisonné of the artist's work. ''We had always hoped that the visibility of the 1950's Indian works would flush others out.''

headline.main: Inside Art

abstract: Carol Vogel Inside Art column; Exhibition Roy Lichtenstein: American Indian Encounters will open at Parrish Art Museum in Southampton, NY, and feature several works by artist that came to light when show originally opened at Montclair Art Museum in 2005; Sotheby's will auction 90 sculptures and paintings from Belgian collectors Roger and Josette Vanthournout; works by Chuck Close on view in Madison Square Park are part of three-city exhibition of public art commisssioned by United Technologies Corp; photo (M)
snippet: “American Indian Encounters’’ at the Parrish Art Museum, works from Roger and Josette Vanthournout to be auctioned at Sotheby’s and life-size portraits of New York’s immigrants at Madison Square Park.

lead_paragraph: In this boomtown of military contractors and veterans, Carla Rock, 36, sat on an aluminum bleacher on a recent afternoon watching her children's tennis lesson and discussing the coming midterm elections. Mrs. Rock said that she was aware of the unease about the war in some parts of the country, and that she was concerned about the nuclear test in North Korea. But over all, she said, America is on the right course.

lead_paragraph: His Sister or Not, She's a Rembrandt When the Rembrandt Research Project first saw ''Portrait of a Young Woman With a Black Cap'' in 1972, the conditions were hardly ideal. The oval painting, which depicts what the project describes as one of several ''Oriental women'' Rembrandt painted, was hanging in the dark corner of a house in Zurich. Although it was signed and the first three digits of the date (1632) were visible, the painting itself seemed odd to members of the project, a committee established in Amsterdam more than 30 years ago by the Dutch government to determine the authenticity of works attributed to this Dutch master. The closer they inspected it, the more evidence against its attribution to Rembrandt mounted. The woman's head looked ''flat and sketchy'' and the construction of the eyes ''slightly squinting,'' according to the research project.

headline.main: Inside Art

lead_paragraph: WHEN one of his competitors raises his ''for sale'' posters higher or another yells, ''Papers!'' louder, Richie Rubertone bends his guitar strings farther apart, pulls his vibrato bar harder and comes up with a catchy lyric. Mr. Rubertone, 40, who said he was laid off four months ago from his plumbing job at a Bronx company, can usually be found on a corner near Madison Square Garden, leaning against his portable metal newsstand. And playing his guitar. He is a blur of color in front of his black and white stacks: red Fender Mustang guitar, silver and black amplifier, shiny leather jacket. He is selling papers, news -- and his music.

lead_paragraph: While ongoing negotiations to buy the beleaguered radio network Air America have kept its future in a state of limbo, the company had one bit of good news last week. WXXM-FM, a station in Madison, Wis., owned by Clear Channel Communications, rescinded a decision to drop the liberal network in favor of Fox Sports Radio. The station, known as ''the Mic'' 92.1, was preparing to switch to a local sports format on Jan. 1. But last Friday, in a surprise statement, the station manager, Jeff Tyler, announced that the station had decided to continue with the progressive talk format of Air America into 2007.

headline.main: Air America Wins Reprieve From a Station In Wisconsin

abstract: WXXM-FM in Madison, Wis, owned by Clear Channel Communications, rescinds decision to drop liberal network Air America in favor of Fox Sports Radio; station manager Jeff Tyler cites overwhelming support for progressive talk format from public, some community leaders and local advertisers (M)
snippet: The station said a public outcry was responsible for the decision to continue with the progressive talk format of Air America.

lead_paragraph: This college town received what it wanted when, during the 1980s and 90s, it sought to reverse the decline of its downtown and to create a more vibrant civic center that would draw people at night and on weekends. Since then, thousands of young professionals, retirees and former suburbanites have moved to glistening condominium buildings in the shadow of the state Capitol's dome and only a few blocks from the University of Wisconsin's main campus. And there is hardly a bad night for business near State Street, where university students and tourists pack restaurants and bars to capacity even on freezing weeknights.

headline.main: Wisconsin City's Revival of Downtown Has a Downside

abstract: Madison, Wis, college town that sought to reverse decline of its downtown in 1980s and 1990s to draw people at night and on weekends, is now facing overcrowding on streets, vandalism and, most significantly, alcohol-related crime; officials are grappling with how to scale down downtown; map; photo (M)
snippet: The revitalization of downtown Madison, Wis., has produced a clash between residents and party crowds.

lead_paragraph: One night in October, a police officer in Madison, a small coastal Connecticut town, called in to dispatchers, telling them that he noticed a door to a restaurant had been left ajar. Not to worry, he said, he would check it out. In went the officer, Joseph R. Gambardella, though he did not use the usual protocol to search for an intruder, like reaching for his weapon or calling for backup, according to a state police officer who investigated the matter. Rather, Officer Gambardella, toting a large trash bag, went right for the freezer.

headline.main: Camera Sees Officer Fishing for Restaurant's Lobster, Authorities Say

snippet: A police officer in Madison stand accused stealing lobster when he was investigating an open door at a restaurant.

lead_paragraph: Generations of New Yorkers have mastered the act of nonchalantly slinking through restaurants and hotel lobbies where they have no business in search of a toilet. But the furtive quest for relief in public may become a fading art starting this summer, now that the city has settled on a site for the first of 20 long-awaited pay toilets. After decades of fits and starts, the city will begin a two-year rollout of 25-cents-a-flush public toilets with the first being installed in Madison Square Park in June, said Kerry Gould, who is overseeing the project for the city's Department of Transportation.

headline.main: Coming to Madison Square Park: Relief at a Quarter a Flush

lead_paragraph: Ablaze in Swirls Of Amber Grain While van Gogh was a patient at an asylum in Saint-Rémy, France, a year before his suicide in 1890, he produced a colorful landscape, ''The Wheat Field Behind St. Paul's Hospital.'' That painting is said to be the first van Gogh to enter a museum. Now it is coming to the United States for the first time when it goes on view at the Neue Galerie in Manhattan as part of ''Van Gogh and Expressionism,'' an exhibition opening on Thursday.

lead_paragraph: It sounds like the setup for a dull economist's joke. Who gets the better deal: the cautious economist who sells his house through a real estate agent, or his risk-taking colleague who finds a buyer on his own? But the question -- debated by two Northwestern University economists who chose different methods to sell their homes -- and the research it helped prompt are serious. And the answer will be of interest to anyone who has paused to consider whether paying a real estate agent's commission, typically 5 to 6 percent of the sale price, is worth it.

headline.main: In One City, Home Sellers Find It Pays to Cut Out Middleman

abstract: Study based on home-sales data from 1998 to 2004 in Madison, Wis, finds people who sold their own homes came out ahead financially of those who used real estate agent; Madison is home to one of biggest for-sale-by-owner Web sits in country; economists who authored study caution that results from Madison may not apply to country as whole; some aspects of their study tilt in agents' favor; homes on multiple listing service sold somewhat faster than houses in for-sale-by-owner site; study is highly unusual in comprehensively measuring impact on sale price of home of hiring, or not hiring, real estate agent; National Assn of Realtors claims houses sold via its members' local multiple listing services get 16 percent premium over homes sold by their owners; economists' study is likely to be seen as ammunition for critics and lower-cost competitors who question need for 5 or 6 percent commissions--which deliver $60 billion a year to agents and their employers; photo; graphs (M)
snippet: Home sellers in Madison, Wis., did not get higher prices for their homes using real estate agents, a study concluded.

lead_paragraph: The Energy Department is creating three bioenergy research centers to find new ways to turn plants into fuel. The three centers, which the department described as three start-up companies with $125 million each in capital, will be in Oak Ridge, Tenn.; Madison, Wis.; and near Berkeley, Calif. They will involve numerous universities, national laboratories and private companies. The goal of the centers, which are to be announced on Tuesday, is to bring new technologies to market within five years.

lead_paragraph: MADISON, Wis. Officer Brent Plisch drove off to start his shift with the campus police, as all around this college town the planets were aligned for undergraduate excess. It was Friday night of the Labor Day long weekend, the eve of the first football game for the highly ranked Wisconsin Badgers. Classes for the fall semester had yet to begin, so there was no homework to tug at the student conscience for moderation, much less temperance.

lead_paragraph: Always a mecca for high-end retailers, Madison Avenue is now attracting a dazzling array of jewelers that are opening new boutiques or occupying larger quarters. Most of the recent burst of development is taking place on a short stretch of the avenue, from 61st through 64th Streets. The neighborhood is becoming a magnet for jewelers in part because it is already home to luxury retailers like Barneys New York, Chanel, Jimmy Choo and Hermès, industry and real estate professionals say. These stores' customers, many of whom live nearby, will no doubt be attracted to high-end jewelry stores.

lead_paragraph: MAD. SQ. ART 2007: 'AROUND THE PARK' There is a meticulous absurdity to William Wegman's ''Around the Park,'' a temporary video installation adjacent to Shake Shack, the popular food kiosk in Madison Square Park. Showing simultaneously on four outdoor television monitors, the video, above, follows two lovely silver-gray Weimaraners, Penny and Bobbin, as they enjoy a day in the park. But this isn't a dog walk -- far from it. Mr. Wegman has dressed the dogs to look like people and then filmed them lounging about on benches, reading books, interacting with each other on the lawn, eating burgers and fries at the kiosk, and even driving around collecting trash. It is a cross between the 1974 television series ''Planet of the Apes'' and ''Saturday Night Live.'' It is also a carefully contrived stunt, with the dogs propped up on stools as hidden actors hold them in place. These actors also provide the dogs with surrogate hands with which to hold food, books and other items. Still, it took Mr. Wegman many days of shooting to get the approximately seven-minute-long footage showing here; the dogs were incredibly skittish and kept darting off whenever they saw a squirrel. (Through Oct. 28, Madison Square Park, 23rd Street and Fifth Avenue, 212-538-4689, madisonsquarepark.org.) BENJAMIN GENOCCHIO

lead_paragraph: What does it take to parlay YouTube stardom into an entertainment career? A year ago, when Matt Sloan was working in a bookstore and Aaron Yonda in a metal shop, they were shooting low-budget comedy films that they showed every week on the local cable-access channel here. When a friend suggested they parody the ''Star Wars'' films, the two were split over the idea of what Mr. Sloan described as ''basically Darth Vader in a grocery store.''

lead_paragraph: As the inner cities, along with much of Florida and the interior of California, face the prospect of a foreclosure meltdown, American college towns appear to be islands of stability. The list of metropolitan areas with the smallest percentage of high-cost home loans is dominated by small cities with big colleges, including Ithaca, N.Y.; Iowa City; Madison, Wis.; Morgantown, W.V.; and State College, Pa.

lead_paragraph: A traveling exhibition of some 200 artworks from the National Museum of Afghanistan in Kabul will begin a 17-month tour in the United States in May, making its first stop at the National Gallery of Art in Washington. The show, organized by the National Gallery with the National Geographic Society, includes objects spanning 4,000 years of Afghanistan's cultural heritage, among them a select group of gold artifacts from the Bactrian hoard, which dates from the first century A.D. The National Gallery stop runs from May 25 through Sept. 7.

It took weight sensors, motion detectors, disinfectant jets, robotic arms and stingy paper dispensers, as well as red, blue, yellow, black and green push buttons to create what city officials called the latest in ''street furniture.''

Though it starts out innocently enough near a row of fast food restaurants on 23rd Street, by the 50s on up Madison Avenue is loaded with stores like Gucci and Prada and Hermès and other even fancier names that the average passer-by is not sophisticated enough to have heard of.

lead_paragraph: MADISON, N.J., is so quaint and charming that people often say the downtown could pass for a movie set -- which probably explains why it has done duty as a setting in films like ''The World According to Garp'' and ''The Family Stone,'' and in episodes of ''The Sopranos.'' But there is much more to Madison than its manicured facade. As home to two colleges -- Drew University and Fairleigh Dickinson University's College at Florham -- this borough of 16,000 residents, 25 miles west of New York, has an international flavor. And by the end of the summer, the area that includes Madison will gain the New York Jets football team, which is completing a corporate headquarters and training facility in Florham Park, on Madison's western border, and a number of executives and players are expected to become Madison residents.

lead_paragraph: ''ARE you with a child?'' This is not a question concertgoers often hear. The concerts are part of the Tuesday and Thursday lineup of events at the park during the summer, thanks to the Madison Square Park Conservancy, perfectly timed to take place before the day gets too hot and the lines at the Shake Shack get too long.

lead_paragraph: A sharply divided Connecticut Supreme Court struck down the state's civil union law on Friday and ruled that same-sex couples have a constitutional right to marry. Connecticut thus joins Massachusetts and California as the only states to have legalized gay marriages. The ruling, which cannot be appealed and is to take effect on Oct. 28, held that a state law limiting marriage to heterosexual couples, and a civil union law intended to provide all the rights and privileges of marriage to same-sex couples, violated the constitutional guarantees of equal protection under the law.

headline.main: Gay Marriage Is Ruled Legal In Connecticut

lead_paragraph: IN the several years since I discovered the Madison Beach Hotel, its seasonal opening, at the end of March, has been the happy signal that spring has been cleared for landing. The hotel is on the site of a roominghouse built in the early 1800s, catering to workers at the nearby shipyard. It maintains an unprepossessing, New England sensibility, with small, reasonably priced rooms, right on the beach. The hotel's adjoining restaurant, the Wharf, used to serve a modified clam-shack menu. Its main attraction has always been its views of Long Island Sound; they are spectacular, whether you're watching through a window on a chilly October day, or from an outside table on the covered porch in the mid-summer sunshine.

lead_paragraph: IT was a brilliant spring morning in Madison Square Park, and the uptown end of the central lawn was already crowded with children playing on a multicolored triangular platform that looked as though it had been made from giant Lego blocks. The children clambered up and down, tossing balls, yelling gleefully and digging in a square of blue rubber mulch that lay on the ground beneath this structure. Their mothers and baby sitters lounged alongside them, sitting on the platform or watching from a set of adjoining turquoise bleachers. At first glance this assemblage might have been mistaken for a particularly inventive playground. But it was actually a piece by the artist Jessica Stockholder, who was watching from the sidelines with Debbie Landau, the president of the Madison Square Park Conservancy, which commissioned the work. Both of them laughed in amazement at the unfolding spectacle.

lead_paragraph: The automated public toilet at National Street and Corona Plaza in Queens -- a self-cleaning contraption that douses itself with disinfectant after each use -- is a prince among lavatories. A stone's throw from the elevated tracks of the No. 7 train, translucent panels jut from a roof topped with a pyramidal skylight. Gender-specific pictographs and Braille text adorn a panel by the door. Inside, revealed for the admission price of 25 cents, is gleaming metalwork and a machine that dispenses toilet paper while making a mewling sound like that of a small wounded animal.

headline.main: A Sidewalk Oasis, if You Can Find One

lead_paragraph: THE Metropolitan Museum of Art's exhibition of the sculpture of Augustus Saint-Gaudens, rich with the work of one of the key figures in the American Renaissance, ends next Sunday. A running theme in the show -- indeed, in Saint-Gaudens's entire life -- is his enduring friendship with the architect Stanford White. As it happens, they were interested in delights not only artistic, but earthly. Saint-Gaudens was born in Dublin in 1848 to a shoemaker and did not get beyond elementary school. At 13, he was apprenticed to a cameo maker; there was then a large demand for small portrait relief busts, often no bigger than a cigarette case.

lead_paragraph: In 2001, six eastern Connecticut artists joined forces to do a little promotion, opening their studios to the public on the same weekend. Now, eight years later, their little promotion has become a big deal around Branford, Guilford and Madison. The Shoreline ArtsTrail Open Studios Weekend, Nov. 21 and 22, will allow visitors to peek into the work spaces, and sometimes the homes, of 38 artists who fuse glass, cut paper, sew fabrics, mold clay, join metal, paint canvas, shape gold and make photographs. The artists will be on hand to discuss their work or demonstrate their methods, and at some of the stops, refreshments will be served.

headline.main: 40 Miles of Creative Spaces

lead_paragraph: WALK down any street of brownstones, and chances are the history you see is fiction, because the typical restoration for old brownstone facades is a nice new coat of stucco. But the case of the old row house at 797 Madison Avenue is one of sedimentary nonfiction, where the usual brownstone repair has been foresworn for, well, brownstone. Madison Avenue was still considered a choice address in 1876 when the developer Robert McCafferty built six brick and brownstone houses, 801-811 Madison, at the southeast corner of 68th. The Real Estate Record and Guide praised the row and called its designer, Richard W. Buckley, ''the rising young architect,'' although such houses were mostly real estate with just a sprinkling of art.

It wasn't particularly nice to walk by.''

lead_paragraph: Judge Barbara Crabb of United States District Court in Madison ruled Thursday that the National Day of Prayer is unconstitutional. Judge Crabb issued the ruling in a lawsuit brought by an atheists and agnostics group, Freedom From Religion Foundation, against former President George W. Bush's administration. The group, based in Madison, argued that the day violated the separation of church and state. Congress established the day in 1952. In 1988, it set the first Thursday in May as the day for presidents to issue proclamations asking Americans to pray.

lead_paragraph: The birds and the bees are in full view across New York's parks these days, but when it comes to another fact of life, the signs can be a little less obvious. In Central Park, where a generous conservancy has attended to every landscaped inch, many maps posted along the way say nothing about any of the 19 free restrooms scattered across its 843 acres. ''If you've got to go to the bathroom, you might have to walk a mile,'' warned Colm O'Connell, a park plumber whom I ran into as I was wandering around looking. ''Some people don't want to do that. They want to go behind a tree. They ask me, 'Can I go?' '' He laughed. ''I'm not a cop, I'm a plumber.''

lead_paragraph: While rescue crews in Philadelphia suspended their search in the Delaware River for two young Hungarian tourists lost in Wednesday's amphibious boat crash, federal investigators focused Thursday on why no distress call had been recorded from the small tourist boat when it stalled on the water minutes before it was gorged by a large passing barge. The crash threw 37 people from the ''duck boat'' into the river, leaving many to bob in life jackets fighting the current as the boat sank. By Thursday, the boat had settled on its six wheels some 50 feet below the surface; a crane was being prepared to haul it up from the depths for clues.

lead_paragraph: Though a familiar sight in New Haven, food carts are rare on the shoreline. But that is where you will find Taco Pacifico, Greg Sharon's taco truck, installed as of July 31 in the parking lot of Dino's Auto Spa on Route 1 in Madison. A native of Harrison, N.Y., Mr. Sharon met authentic Mexican food in Southern California, where he lived for two and a half years. With no formal culinary training, he taught himself by watching and eating at his neighborhood taquerias in and around Van Nuys.

lead_paragraph: At this Italian restaurant on Madison Avenue between 97th and 98th Streets, the appeal of eating local has nothing to do with the provenance of the food. Opened in February and with Salvatore Fraterrigo as the executive chef, Tre Otto was carved out of an old dress shop by Lauren and Louis Cangiano, who live around the corner. He comes from a family that ran Italian specialty supermarkets for decades on Staten Island and in Brooklyn; she is a real estate agent. With exposed-brick walls, dark-wood furnishings and a menu including casual starters and composed entrees, the place has quickly found a following among residents -- of both the neighborhood and medical variety -- at the crossroads of Carnegie Hill and East Harlem, near Mount Sinai Medical Center. On Wednesday, that following included a group of medical professionals talking shop. IN THE SEATS Dr. Natan Bar-Chama, a urologist who directs male reproductive medicine and surgery at Mount Sinai Hospital and teaches in its medical school, and three executives from American Medical Systems: Gary Nava, Ray Tantillo and Geoff Higgins. The company, based in Minnetonka, Minn., makes devices to correct erectile, incontinence and other pelvic problems.

headline.main: Medical Talk, With Antipasti and Pasta on the Side

snippet: An Italian restaurant that opened in February near Mount Sinai Medical Center already has a fan base in the neighborhood.

lead_paragraph: THE tiny soldiers that are the stars of Burlington Toys, a subterranean store at 1082 Madison Avenue, survived intact, but the Pee-wee Herman doll was put in harm's way recently when a boiler burst and hot water cascaded inside. The store is a bizarre basement wonderland crammed with collectibles. It's down a set of creaky stairs from the Crawford Doyle Booksellers, an independent, oddball gem once known as Burlington Books three decades ago, when the toy soldiers, spaceships, robots and miniature trains moved in, along with Steve Balkin. Mr. Balkin, who is 72 and beset by pulmonary aggravations, is still their enthusiastic curator and, in some cases, creator. He built the brass rockets himself.

lead_paragraph: MADISON, Wis. -- President Obama, seeking to avert potentially devastating losses for Democrats on Election Day, delivered an impassioned appeal to a cheering throng of college students here Tuesday night, telling them to ''keep believing change is possible'' and pleading, ''You've got to stick with me, you can't lose heart.'' In a 45-minute speech on a packed green in front of the library at the University of Wisconsin-Madison, Mr. Obama reached back to the soaring rhetoric that carried him to the White House in 2008. The old-fashioned get-out-the-vote rally, in a brisk wind under gray skies, seemed to energize the president as much as the crowd.

headline.main: 'Stick With Me,' Obama Urges Students

snippet: Recalling the themes of his own campaign, the president said change was still possible.

lead_paragraph: THE super-luxe new Ralph Lauren palazzo, at the southwest corner of Madison Avenue and 72nd Street, is scheduled to open in mid-October. But across the street, hidden for months behind a veil of netting, is the old store, a limestone mansion with a mournful past, built in 1898 by an heiress who never lived in it. Gertrude Rhinelander was born about 1837 into a family that had lived in New York since the 17th century, and in 1876 she married Francis Waldo, a stockbroker who had been ruined in the Panic of 1873. Her lifestyle, however, was never less than genteel; at her death in 1914, The New York Sun said she had inherited $2 million.

headline.main: Mrs. Waldo's Mysterious Mansion

lead_paragraph: Paul B. Martinez fell in love with carnations 52 years ago. He was 13, a poor kid growing up in East Harlem, where his Puerto Rican-born father ran a bodega with his uncle. When a guy named Nick, who owned the combination hot dog stand/flower shop next door, needed a delivery boy, Mr. Martinez took the job: 50 cents per trip, mostly carnations and gladioluses destined for neighborhood funeral homes. Now 65, he is a designer and manager at Flowers by Philip on Madison Avenue, owned by Philip Mercedes. He lives in Yorkville with his wife, Puma. The meaning of carnations: They were the first flowers I was exposed to. When you went to church on Mother's Day, you wore a white carnation if your mother was deceased, red if she was alive, and pink if she was alive but lived far away. Carnations cost about 8 cents then. When Nick had work for me, he'd go out his back door and holler up at our apartment: ''Mrs. Martinez, I need Paul for a delivery!'' I worked for him for two years until I went to Aviation High School in Queens. I wanted to be a pilot. I still do.

headline.main: For the Rich, It's Always Special Arrangements

lead_paragraph: BAR BOUCHON is so hot it sizzles. It is already so mobbed that I felt lucky to snag a 4:30 p.m. dinner reservation one recent Saturday. It was worth it.

lead_paragraph: I was 10 and a half years old and having dinner with my father, who covered the Green Bay Packers as a sportscaster, and Marv Fleming, the rangy, elegant tight end Bart Starr would calmly seek out when the dirt-stained jerseys of the Bears or the Giants writhed in front of all his other options. It was the fall of 1967, and my father and I both remember Fleming wearing the first of his Super Bowl rings on the longest fingers either of us had ever seen. I blurted the question I had saved up -- ''Mr. Fleming, what is the secret to your success?'' -- and waited for him to explain the gym routines or agility drills that had elevated him above other athletes.

lead_paragraph: MADISON, Wis. -- In a capital city overrun for much of the past week by union supporters, state employees and students -- all objecting to the Republican governor's plan to cut collective bargaining rights and benefits for public workers -- a new element was introduced on Saturday: opposition to the opposition. All around the Capitol square, tens of thousands of union supporters chanted, as they have for days: ''Kill the bill! Kill the bill!'' In one corner, a far smaller contingent of demonstrators, many of whom described themselves as Tea Party members, chanted: ''Pass the bill! Pass the bill!''

headline.main: Dueling Demonstrations in a Capital Where Nothing Much Is Getting Done

lead_paragraph: MADISON, Wis. -- Someday the ruckus here might be remembered as the Pizza-Powered People's Uprising. Every day for the past week, the two Ian's Pizza shops in town have fed the hungry masses, delivering hundreds of free pies to the Capitol. The owners of Ian's boasted that supporters from all 50 states -- as well as Bosnia, China, Egypt, France and 20 other countries -- had donated thousands of dollars each day so they could give protesters the calories they needed to keep going.

headline.main: Delivering Moral Support In a Steady Stream of Pizzas

abstract: Ian's Pizza shops in Madison, Wis, have received thousands of dollars from donors all over the world to provide free pizza to the throngs of protesters opposing Gov Scott Walker's push to curb collective bargaining rights for state workers; on one day alone, Ian's delivered nearly 800 pies to the Capitol grounds; photos (M)
snippet: Donors from around the country, and the world, have kept the Wisconsin protesters well fed.

lead_paragraph: IT seems like bait and switch. People who spent their working lives believing that they could retire at 65 or so are looking at their financial statements and thinking that it can't be done. The recession -- and maybe their own spending -- took too big a bite out of their balances. Many people are willing, and even eager, to keep working until they can build up their retirement savings. But for those who long to retire sooner rather than later, there is a way out of workaday life that can be leveraged to great advantage -- moving to a lower-cost area.

headline.main: One Secret To Clocking Out May Be A Moving Van

abstract: Older working people who long to retire can move to lower-cost area; differences between high-cost and low-cost--but still attractive--areas can be steep and make a big impact on a fixed income; photo (M)
snippet: Deciding to sell a longtime home and move away from friends and family can be wrenching, but it might be better than trying to rebuild decimated retirement savings.

lead_paragraph: The protesters who camped out in the Wisconsin Capitol building in Madison for nearly three weeks hung a handwritten placard over the marble bust of Robert La Follette, the state's titan of progressivism. ''What Would Bob Do?'' it begged, a plaintive appeal to recall the state's history on the forefront for workers' rights as the protesters try to fend off Scott Walker, the new Republican governor, who insists that he will not compromise in his bid to all but eliminate collective bargaining for public unions.

lead_paragraph: It was the looming threat of a lease expiration that would open up 200,000 square feet of space occupied by UBS and other tenants that persuaded the owners of 535 Madison Avenue to invest in the building's first major upgrades in more than two decades. That the wager, at a cost of more than $5 million, was made in 2009 at the depths of the market only made it riskier. But with lobby, elevator and electrical renovations now complete at the 37-story office tower, the building's owners say the bet is already paying off. Since last year, more than half of the 200,000 square feet UBS vacated has been leased, with much of the common space spruced up just as the Manhattan office leasing market begins to show signs of improvement.

headline.main: New York Office Renovations in Downturn Pay Off

snippet: As New York rents fell during the downturn, some building owners who were unwilling or unable to invest in new construction refurbished their property instead.

What sort of tumult might this bring?

lead_paragraph: When Fawn Nebinger ran a gallery several years ago, she named it after a favorite kind of flower. The moniker, Foxglove, has lingered on, even as her business evolved from paintings, to bath and beauty items, to cheese. Many of the bath accouterments are still available at her store, Foxglove and Madison Cheese, along with sundry crackers, jams and snack items. But the central focus of the business is clearly on cheese. The cooler case at the front of the store displays more than 40 varieties, and several more are kept out of sight in an adjacent refrigerator. A number of them are made from raw milk.

lead_paragraph: OVER the last decade Jaume Plensa has become one of the world's most celebrated public artists, best known for wondrously monumental figurative sculptures that can be seen from Calgary to Dubai. But ask this Barcelona native how he creates his work, which seems to involve feats of technology as well as imagination, and he prefers to talk about music, dreams and poetry. ''Shakespeare is the best definition of sculpture,'' he might say, quoting the ''sleep no more'' soliloquy from Macbeth. ''You are working always with physical elements. You are always touching, touching. But you can't describe it.''

headline.main: Monuments: The Poetry Of Dreams

lead_paragraph: It has become something of an annual tradition at the Matthew Marks Gallery to invite one of its artists to organize a summer exhibition, and this year it is Thomas Demand. He has taken over the gallery's West 22nd Street space in Chelsea, reconfiguring it with an installation of labyrinthine walls based on a drawing by the artist Martin Boyce and presenting a show opening Tuesday called ''La Carte d'Après Nature.'' The title is taken from the name of an art journal published sporadically by Magritte between 1951 and 1965. It consisted mainly of simple postcards by friends as well as his own work.

headline.main: An Artist Shows His Train of Thought

lead_paragraph: Last night, New Yorkers donned their most minimal attire and headed to the Calvin Klein flagship on Madison Avenue to introduce Americans for Marriage Equality USA, an advocacy program that promotes "love, family and commitment" and the rights of gays and lesbians to wed. The event, hosted by the Human Rights Campaign (HRC), was buzzing with post-holiday excitement -- everyone catching up on where they went, what they cooked and who they shared it with. In a toast to the organization, the HRC executive director, Joe Solmonese, thanked New York City Council Speaker Christine Quinn. "The conscience of this fight is Christine - she brought it all. Her truth, her story and her courage," he said. Among those in attendance (and enjoying the tunnel of light sculpture by the British artist Nathaniel Rackowe and music by DJ Coleman) were such notable guests as the comedian Jerry Seinfeld and his wife, Jessica, the author Jay McInerney, the model Karen Elson and the business tycoon Ron Perelman. Because everyone there had marriage on their minds, T went ahead and asked some what commitment means to them:

lead_paragraph: It was to be our "Pretty Woman" moment: four stories of unbridled luxury nestled on the corner of Madison Ave and 66th Street; two young men's-wear enthusiasts from way, way downtown with permission to run wild. Our target was the newly renovated Giorgio Armani boutique on the Upper East Side, which opened on Feb. 15 with much ado and for good reason. The airy space has all the characteristics of a luxury brand flagship: textured Marmarino walls and ceilings, custom Armani/Casa furniture and fixtures, large windows, changing rooms bigger than your bedroom and a constant stream of older, moneyed men and women who don't even flinch at the hefty price tags ($945 for a pair of jeans, $4,000 for a jacket, $500 for a button-down shirt).
